paragraphs.original: A tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard Enter a MASTER and a BOATSWAIN
paragraphs.translated:
Loud noises of a storm with thunder and lightning. A ship's MASTER and
BOATSWAIN enter.

paragraphs.original: Boatswain!
paragraphs.translated: Boatswain!

paragraphs.original: Here, master. What cheer?
paragraphs.translated: I'm here, sir. How can I help you?

paragraphs.original: Good, speak to th' mariners. Fall to 't yarely, or we run ourselves aground. Bestir, bestir.
paragraphs.translated: My good boy, give the other sailors a pep talk - and do it fast, before we're shipwrecked. Hurry, hurry!

paragraphs.original: Exit MASTER
paragraphs.translated: The MASTER exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARINERS
paragraphs.translated: SAILORS enter.

paragraphs.original:
Heigh, my hearts! Cheerly, cheerly, my hearts! Yare! Yare!
Take in the topsail. - Tend to th' master's whistle. - Blow, till thou burst thy wind, if room enough!
paragraphs.translated: Come on, men! That's the way to do it! Quickly! Quickly! Take in the upper sail. Listen to the master's orders.  - Blow your heart out, storm! So long as we have enough room to avoid running aground!

paragraphs.original: Enter ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, FERDINAND, GONZALO, and others
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, FERDINAND, GONZALO, and others enter.

paragraphs.original:
Good Boatswain, have care. Where's the Master?
Play the men.
paragraphs.translated: Be careful, good Boatswain! Where's the Master? Make these men work.

paragraphs.original: I pray now, keep below.
paragraphs.translated: Please stay below deck, sir.

paragraphs.original: Where is the Master, Boatswain?
paragraphs.translated: Where's the Master, Boatswain?

paragraphs.original:
Do you not hear him? You mar our labor. Keep your cabins.
You do assist the storm.
paragraphs.translated: He's busy, can't you hear him giving orders? You're getting in the way of our work. Stay in your cabins. You're helping the storm, not us.

paragraphs.original: Nay, good, be patient.
paragraphs.translated: Don't get wound up, my good man.

paragraphs.original: When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers for the name of king? To cabin, silence! Trouble us not.
paragraphs.translated: I'm only wound up because the sea's wound up. Now get out of here! Do you think these waves care anything about kings and officials? Go to your cabins and be quiet! Don't bother us up here.

paragraphs.original: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.
paragraphs.translated: Just remember who you've got on board with you, good man.

paragraphs.original: None that I more love than myself. You are a councilor. If you can command these elements to silence and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more. Use your authority. If you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap. - Cheerly, good hearts! - Out of our way, I say.
paragraphs.translated: Nobody I care about more than myself. You're a king's advisor. If you can order the storm to calm down, we can all put down our ropes and rest. Go ahead, use your authority. If you can't do it, be grateful you've lived this long and go wait to die in your cabin, if it comes to that. - Harder, men! - Now get out of our way, I'm telling you.

paragraphs.original: Exit BOATSWAIN
paragraphs.translated: The BOATSWAIN exits.

paragraphs.original: I have great comfort from this fellow. Methinks he hath no drowning mark upon him. His complexion is perfect gallows. Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging. Make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our own doth little advantage. If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.
paragraphs.translated:
I feel a lot better after talking to this guy. He doesn't look like a person who would drown - he looks like he was born to be
hanged. I hope he lives long enough to be hanged. The rope that hangs him will do more good than all the ropes on this ship, since it'll guarantee he stays alive through this storm. But if he's not destined to die by hanging, then our chances don't look too good.
hanged

paragraphs.original: Exeunt GONZALO and courtiers
paragraphs.translated: GONZALO exits with the other men of court.

paragraphs.original: Enter BOATSWAIN
paragraphs.translated: The BOATSWAIN enters.

paragraphs.original: Down with the topmast! Yare, lower, lower! Bring her to try wi' th' main course.
paragraphs.translated: Bring down that top sail! Fast! Lower, lower! Let the ship sail close to the wind.

paragraphs.original: A cry within
paragraphs.translated: A shout offstage.

paragraphs.original: A plague upon this howling! They are louder than the weather or our office.
paragraphs.translated: Damn those men shouting down there! They're louder than the storm or us sailors.

paragraphs.original: Enter SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, and GONZALO
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, and GONZALO enter.

paragraphs.original:
Yet again? What do you here? Shall we give o'er and drown?
Have you a mind to sink?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, not you again. What do you want? Should we all give up and drown? Do you want to sink?

paragraphs.original: A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, go to hell, you loud-mouthed bastard!

paragraphs.original: Work you, then.
paragraphs.translated: Well, get to work, then.

paragraphs.original: Hang, cur! Hang, you whoreson insolent noisemaker! We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
paragraphs.translated: Just die, you lowlife! Go ahead and die, you nasty, rude bastard!You're more scared of drowning than we are.

paragraphs.original: I'll warrant him for drowning though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an unstanched wench.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I guarantee he won't drown - even if this ship were as fragile as an eggshell and as leaky as a menstruating woman.

paragraphs.original:
Lay her a-hold, a-hold! Set her two courses off to sea again.
Lay her off!
paragraphs.translated: Turn the ship to the wind! Set the sails and let her go out to sea again!

paragraphs.original: Enter MARINERS, wet
paragraphs.translated: More SAILORS enter, wet.

paragraphs.original: All lost! To prayers, to prayers, all lost!
paragraphs.translated: It's no use! Pray for your lives! We're done for!

paragraphs.original: Exit MARINERS
paragraphs.translated: The SAILORS exit.

paragraphs.original: What, must our mouths be cold?
paragraphs.translated: What, we're going to die?

paragraphs.original: The king and prince at prayers. Let's assist them, for our case is as theirs.
paragraphs.translated: The king and the prince are praying. Let's go join them, since whatever happens to them happens to us too.

paragraphs.original: I'm out of patience.
paragraphs.translated: I'm out of patience.

paragraphs.original: We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards. This wide-chopped rascal - would thou mightst lie drowning the washing of ten tides!
He'll be hanged yet, though every drop of water swear against it and gape at widest to glut him.
paragraphs.translated: He'll still die by hanging, not drowning, even if every drop of water in the sea tries to swallow him.

paragraphs.original: A confused noise within
paragraphs.translated: A confused noise offstage.

paragraphs.original:
(within) Mercy on us! - We split, we split! - Farewell, my wife and children! - Farewell, brother! - We split, we split, we split!
(within)
paragraphs.translated: God have mercy on us! - The ship's breaking up! - Goodbye, wife and kids! - Goodbye, brother! - We're breaking up, we're breaking up!

paragraphs.original: Let's all sink wi' th' king.
paragraphs.translated: Let's all sink with the king.

paragraphs.original: Let's take leave of him.
paragraphs.translated: Let's say goodbye to him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN exit.

paragraphs.original: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground: long heath, brown furze, anything. The wills above be done, but I would fain die a dry death.
paragraphs.translated:
Right now I'd give a thousand
furlongs of sea for one little acre of dry ground: barren weed patch, anything at all. What's destined to happen will happen, but I'd give anything to be dry when I die.
furlongs

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter PROSPERO and MIRANDA
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO and MIRANDA enter.

paragraphs.original:
If by your art, my dearest father, you have
Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch,
But that the sea, mounting to th' welkin's cheek,
Dashes the fire out. Oh, I have suffered
With those that I saw suffer. A brave vessel
Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her
Dashed all to pieces. Oh, the cry did knock
Against my very heart! Poor souls, they perished.
Had I been any god of power, I would
Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere
It should the good ship so have swallowed and
The fraughting souls within her.
paragraphs.translated: Dear father, if you caused this terrible storm with your magic powers, please put an end to it. The sky's so dark it looks like it would rain down boiling hot tar if the sea weren't swelling up to the sky to put its fire out. Oh, I suffered along with all the men I watched suffer! A fine ship, with some good people in it, I'm sure, smashed to pieces. Their dying shouts broke my heart! The poor people died. If I'd been a god I would've let the sea sink inside the earth before it had a chance to swallow up that ship and all the people it was carrying.

paragraphs.original:
Be collected.
No more amazement. Tell your piteous heart
There's no harm done.
paragraphs.translated: Calm down. There's nothing to get upset about. No harm was done.

paragraphs.original: Oh, woe the day!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what a horrible day!

paragraphs.original:
No harm.
I have done nothing but in care of thee,
Of thee, my dear one - thee my daughter, who
Art ignorant of what thou art, naught knowing
Of whence I am, nor that I am more better
Than Prospero, master of a full poor cell
And thy no greater father.
paragraphs.translated: There was no harm, I'm telling you. Everything I've done has been for you, my dear daughter. You don't know what you are, since you don't know who I am or where I come from, or that I'm better than merely Prospero, your humble father who lives in a poor little shack.

paragraphs.original:
More to know
Did never meddle with my thoughts.
paragraphs.translated: It never occurred to me to imagine there was anything more to know.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis time
I should inform thee farther. Lend thy hand
And pluck my magic garment from me.
paragraphs.translated: It's time for you to know the whole story. Give me a hand and help me off with this magic cloak.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA helps PROSPERO remove his mantle
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA helps PROSPERO remove his cloak.

paragraphs.original:
So,
Lie there, my art. - Wipe thou thine eyes. Have comfort.
The direful spectacle of the wrack, which touched
The very virtue of compassion in thee,
I have with such provision in mine art
So safely ordered that there is no soul - 
No, not so much perdition as an hair
Betid to any creature in the vessel - 
Which thou heard'st cry, which thou sawst sink. Sit down.
For thou must now know farther.
paragraphs.translated:
(to the cloak) So, lie there, my magic. (to MIRANDA) Wipe your eyes. Take comfort. I arranged the horrible sight of this shipwreck, which moved you to such pity, so carefully that not a single person was hurt - no, not so much as a hair on anyone's head was destroyed in the ship that you saw sink. Sit down. It's time for you to know more. (they sit)
(to the cloak)
(to
)
they sit

paragraphs.original:
You have often
Begun to tell me what I am, but stopped
And left me to a bootless inquisition,
Concluding, "Stay. Not yet."
paragraphs.translated: You've often started to tell me who I am, but then suddenly stopped, leaving me asking questions that never get answered, telling me, "Wait. Not yet."

paragraphs.original:
The hour's now come.
The very minute bids thee ope thine ear.
Obey and be attentive. Canst thou remember
A time before we came unto this cell?
I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not
Out three years old.
paragraphs.translated: Well, the time has come. This is the moment for you to listen hard and pay close attention. Can you remember the time before you came to live in this shack? I doubt it, since you weren't even three at the time.

paragraphs.original: Certainly, sir, I can.
paragraphs.translated: Sure I can, father.

paragraphs.original:
By what? By any other house or person?
Of anything the image tell me that
Hath kept with thy remembrance.
paragraphs.translated: What do you remember? A house, a person? Tell me anything you remember.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis far off,
And rather like a dream than an assurance
That my remembrance warrants. Had I not
Four or five women once that tended me?
paragraphs.translated: My memory is hazy, more like a dream than a recollection. Didn't I use to have four or five women taking care of me?

paragraphs.original:
Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is it
That this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else
In the dark backward and abysm of time?
If thou rememberest aught ere thou camest here,
How thou camest here thou mayst.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed you did, and more besides, Miranda. But how is it possible that you still remember this, through all the darkness of the past? If you remember your life before you came here, you may also remember how you got here.

paragraphs.original: But that I do not.
paragraphs.translated: No, that I don't remember.

paragraphs.original:
Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since,
Thy father was the Duke of Milan and
A prince of power.
paragraphs.translated: Twelve years ago, Miranda, twelve years ago your father was the Duke of Milan, a powerful prince.

paragraphs.original: Sir, are not you my father?
paragraphs.translated: Aren't you my father?

paragraphs.original:
Thy mother was a piece of virtue and
She said thou wast my daughter. And thy father
Was Duke of Milan, and thou his only heir
And princess no worse issued.
paragraphs.translated: Your mother was extremely virtuous, and she said you were my daughter. And your father was Duke of Milan, and you were his heir, a princess.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, the heavens!
What foul play had we that we came from thence?
Or blessè was 't we did?
paragraphs.translated: Good lord! What evil things were done to us that we were driven here? Or was it a blessing that we came here?

paragraphs.original:
Both, both, my girl.
By foul play, as thou sayst, were we heaved thence,
But blessedly holp hither.
paragraphs.translated: Both, both, my girl. We were pushed out of power by evil deeds, as you call them. But we were blessed in being helped toward this island.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, my heart bleeds
To think o' th' teen that I have turned you to,
Which is from my remembrance! Please you, farther.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, it breaks my heart to think how painful it must be for you to recall all this, things that I can't remember. But please tell me more.

paragraphs.original:
My brother and thy uncle, called Antonio - 
I pray thee, mark me (that a brother should
Be so perfidious!) - he whom next thyself
Of all the world I loved and to him put
The manage of my state, as at that time
Through all the signories it was the first,
And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed
In dignity, and for the liberal arts
Without a parallel. Those being all my study,
The government I cast upon my brother
And to my state grew stranger, being transported
And rapt in secret studies. Thy false uncle - 
Dost thou attend me?
paragraphs.translated: My brother, your uncle Antonio - just listen to this (I still can't believe a brother could be so disloyal!) - My brother whom - aside from you - I loved more than anyone else in the world, I trusted to run my state, which at that time was the strongest in the land, and Prospero the number one duke, famous for my dignity and my education. Since I was so drawn to studying things like logic, grammar, geometry, and astronomy, I let my control of the government slide a bit, being too wrapped up in my occult books. Your disloyal uncle - are you paying attention?

paragraphs.original: Sir, most heedfully.
paragraphs.translated: I'm hanging on every word.

paragraphs.original:
Being once perfected how to grant suits,
How to deny them, who t' advance and who
To trash for overtopping, new created
The creatures that were mine, I say - or changed 'em,
Or else new formed 'em - having both the key
Of officer and office, set all hearts i' th' state
To what tune pleased his ear, that now he was
The ivy which had hid my princely trunk,
And sucked my verdure out on 't. Thou attend'st not.
paragraphs.translated: Once Antonio got the knack of granting certain requests, denying others, promoting some officials and keeping down those who were getting too ambitious, he won over the people who used to be mine, or changed them - remade them, you might say. Since he had control over the whole government and everyone in it, he soon made everyone sing his own song - whichever song he happened to like. He became like the ivy that sticks to the side of the tree, and sucked my vitality out of me. - You're not paying attention.

paragraphs.original: O, good sir, I do.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, yes I am, father.

paragraphs.original:
I pray thee, mark me.
I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated
To closeness and the bettering of my mind
With that which, but by being so retired,
O'erprized all popular rate, in my false brother
Awaked an evil nature. And my trust,
Like a good parent, did beget of him
A falsehood in its contrary as great
As my trust was, which had indeed no limit,
A confidence sans bound. He being thus lorded,
Not only with what my revenue yielded
But what my power might else exact, like one
Who having into truth, by telling of it,
Made such a sinner of his memory
To credit his own lie - he did believe
He was indeed the duke, out o' th' substitution
And executing th' outward face of royalty,
With all prerogative. Hence his ambition growing - 
Dost thou hear?
paragraphs.translated: Please listen to me carefully. As I neglected practical matters, being totally dedicated to solitude and to improving my mind with subjects more valuable than most people imagine, I was so shut away from the world that I unwittingly stirred up evil wishes in my disloyal brother. My deep trust in him made him deeply untrustworthy, arousing in him a treachery as big as my trust was - my trust which had no limit, an infinite confidence. With Antonio possessing such powers and wealth, coming not only from my income but also from his ability to take whatever my authority allowed him to take, Antonio started to believe that he was the duke, like some liar who begins to believe in his own lie. He put on the face of royalty, with all the rights that go along with it. With his ambition growing like this - do you hear what I'm saying?

paragraphs.original: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.
paragraphs.translated: What you're saying could cure deafness, father. Of course I hear it.

paragraphs.original:
To have no screen between this part he played
And him he played it for, he needs will be
Absolute Milan. Me, poor man, my library
Was dukedom large enough. Of temporal royalties
He thinks me now incapable, confederates - 
So dry he was for sway - wi' th' King of Naples
To give him annual tribute, do him homage,
Subject his coronet to his crown and bend
The dukedom yet unbowed - alas, poor Milan! - 
To most ignoble stooping.
paragraphs.translated: To make his political performance absolutely perfect, he simply had to become the Duke of Milan himself. My library was a large enough dukedom for me. So, now Antonio judges me incapable of carrying out my duties. He's so power-hungry that he allies himself with the King of Naples, agreeing to pay him a regular annual sum, swear subservience to him, and put the dukedom of Milan - never subservient to anyone before! - under the humiliating control of Naples.

paragraphs.original: Oh, the heavens!
paragraphs.translated: Good heavens!

paragraphs.original:
Mark his condition and the event. Then tell me
If this might be a brother.
paragraphs.translated: Think about that, and about what followed afterward. Then tell me if Antonio can be called a brother.

paragraphs.original:
I should sin
To think but nobly of my grandmother.
Good wombs have borne bad sons.
paragraphs.translated: It would be wrong for me to think poorly of my grandmother. Good women sometimes give birth to bad sons.

paragraphs.original:
Now the condition.
The King of Naples, being an enemy
To me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit,
Which was that he, in lieu o' th' premises
Of homage and I know not how much tribute,
Should presently extirpate me and mine
Out of the dukedom, and confer fair Milan
With all the honors on my brother. Whereon,
A treacherous army levied, one midnight
Fated to th' purpose did Antonio open
The gates of Milan, and, i' th' dead of darkness,
The ministers for th' purpose hurried thence
Me and thy crying self.
paragraphs.translated: Now listen to the agreement they made. The king of Naples, my arch-enemy, listens to my brother's request, which was that the king, in exchange for the respect and money paid to him, would get rid of me and make my brother Duke of Milan instead. A treacherous army was gathered, and one fateful night at midnight, Antonio opened the gates of Milan, and in the pitch black had his officers rush out me and you, my dear daughter. You were crying.

paragraphs.original:
Alack, for pity!
I, not remembering how I cried out then,
Will cry it o'er again. It is a hint
That wrings mine eyes to 't.
paragraphs.translated: How awful! I can't remember how I cried then, but I'll cry all over again. This story breaks my heart.

paragraphs.original:
Hear a little further
And then I'll bring thee to the present business
Which now 's upon 's, without the which this story
Were most impertinent.
paragraphs.translated: Just listen a little more, and I'll bring you up to date about the present situation, which is the whole reason I'm telling you this story in the first place.

paragraphs.original:
Wherefore did they not
That hour destroy us?
paragraphs.translated: Why didn't they just kill us that night?

paragraphs.original:
Well demanded, wench.
My tale provokes that question. Dear, they durst not,
So dear the love my people bore me, nor set
A mark so bloody on the business, but
With colors fairer painted their foul ends.
In few, they hurried us aboard a bark,
Bore us some leagues to sea, where they prepared
A rotten carcass of a butt, not rigged,
Nor tackle, sail, nor mast. The very rats
Instinctively had quit it. There they hoist us
To cry to th' sea that roared to us, to sigh
To th' winds whose pity, sighing back again,
Did us but loving wrong.
paragraphs.translated: Good question, my girl. My story does raise that question. The answer, my dear, is that they didn't dare, because the people of Milan loved me too much. The had to disguise their bloody intentions. So, to make a long story short, they hurried us onto a ship and carried us a number of miles out to sea, where they prepared a rotten carcass of a boat, with no sails or masts or ropes, which even the rats had abandoned. They tossed us in the water to cry to the sea that roared back at us, to sigh into the winds that sighed right back at us in pity.

paragraphs.original:
Alack, what trouble
Was I then to you!
paragraphs.translated: God, what a burden on you I must have been!

paragraphs.original:
Oh, a cherubim
Thou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile
Infusèd with a fortitude from heaven,
When I have decked the sea with drops full salt,
Under my burthen groaned; which raised in me
An undergoing stomach to bear up
Against what should ensue.
paragraphs.translated: No, my dear, you were a little angel who kept me going. You smiled with a strength you must have gotten from heaven, while I cried salty tears into the salty sea, and groaned at our situation. Your smile sustained my spirits against whatever would come our way.

paragraphs.original: How came we ashore?
paragraphs.translated: How did we manage to get ashore?

paragraphs.original:
By providence divine.
Some food we had and some fresh water that
A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo,
Out of his charity, who being then appointed
Master of this design, did give us, with
Rich garments, linens, stuffs, and necessaries,
Which since have steaded much. So, of his gentleness,
Knowing I loved my books, he furnished me
From mine own library with volumes that
I prize above my dukedom.
paragraphs.translated: With God's help. We had a little food and fresh water that a nobleman from Naples, Gonzalo, had given us out of the kindness of his heart. He had been chosen to carry out the plan of putting us to sea. He also gave us clothes, linen, and other necessities that have been of great help. Knowing how much I loved my books, he gave me some books from my library that I value more than my dukedom.

paragraphs.original:
Would I might
But ever see that man!
paragraphs.translated: I wish I could see that man someday!

paragraphs.original:
Now I arise.
(stands and puts on his mantle)
(stands and puts on his mantle)
Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow.
Here in this island we arrived, and here
Have I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profit
Than other princesses can that have more time
For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.
paragraphs.translated:
Now I'll stand up. (he stands and puts on his magic cloak) Sit still and listen to the last of our sad sea adventures. We arrived here on this island, where I, acting as your teacher, have given you a better education than most princesses get, princesses who have less careful tutors, who spend their time instead on empty fun.
(he stands and puts on his magic cloak)

paragraphs.original:
Heavens thank you for 't! And now, I pray you, sir - 
For still 'tis beating in my mind - your reason
For raising this sea storm?
paragraphs.translated: May God thank you for it. But please, father - the question is still nagging at me - why did you conjure up this storm?

paragraphs.original:
Know thus far forth:
By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune
(Now my dear lady) hath mine enemies
Brought to this shore. And by my prescience
I find my zenith doth depend upon
A most auspicious star, whose influence
If now I court not but omit, my fortunes
Will ever after droop. Here cease more questions.
paragraphs.translated: You should know this: much luck is on my side, and my enemies have happened to wreck their ship on this island. As I see it, my fate hangs on this lucky event, and if I handle it wrong, I'll suffer for the rest of my life. Now, no more questions.

paragraphs.original:
Thou art inclined to sleep. 'Tis a good dullness,
And give it way. I know thou canst not choose.
paragraphs.translated: You look sleepy. It's a nice hazy feeling, so give in to it. I know you have no choice.

paragraphs.original: MIRANDA sleeps
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA falls asleep.

paragraphs.original:
Come away, servant, come. I am ready now.
Approach, my Ariel, come.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, servant, come. I'm ready now. Come here, Ariel.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters.

paragraphs.original:
All hail, great master! Grave sir, hail! I come
To answer thy best pleasure, be 't to fly,
To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride
On the curled clouds. To thy strong bidding, task
Ariel and all his quality.
paragraphs.translated: Humble greetings, great master! Worthy sir, greetings! Your wish is my command, whatever you want. If you want me to fly, to swim, to jump into fire, to ride the clouds in the sky, Ariel will get right to the task.

paragraphs.original:
Hast thou, spirit,
Performed to point the tempest that I bade thee?
paragraphs.translated: Spirit, did you carry out the storm just as I ordered?

paragraphs.original:
To every article.
I boarded the king's ship. Now on the beak,
Now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin,
I flamed amazement. Sometime I'd divide,
And burn in many places. On the topmast,
The yards, and bowsprit would I flame distinctly,
Then meet and join. Jove's lightning, the precursors
O' th' dreadful thunderclaps, more momentary
And sight-outrunning were not. The fire and cracks
Of sulfurous roaring the most mighty Neptune
Seem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble,
Yea, his dread trident shake.
paragraphs.translated: Down to the last detail. I boarded the king's ship, and in every corner of it, from the deck to the cabins, I made everyone astonished and terrified. Sometimes I appeared in many places at once. On the top sail and main mast I flamed in different spots, then I came together into a single flame. I flashed about faster than lightning. The fire and deafening cracks seemed to overwhelm even the god of the sea himself, making him tremble underwater.

paragraphs.original:
My brave spirit!
Who was so firm, so constant, that this coil
Would not infect his reason?
paragraphs.translated: Good spirit! Who could ever be so steady and strong that a disturbance like that wouldn't make him crazy?

paragraphs.original:
Not a soul
But felt a fever of the mad and played
Some tricks of desperation. All but mariners
Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel,
Then all afire with me. The king's son, Ferdinand,
With hair up-staring - then, like reeds, not hair - 
Was the first man that leaped, cried, "Hell is empty
And all the devils are here."
paragraphs.translated: Everyone there got a little crazy and pulled some desperate stunts. Everyone except the sailors dove into the sea, leaving behind the ship that I had set on fire. The king's son, Ferdinand, with his hair standing straight up - it looked like reeds, not hair - was the first person to jump, shouting, "Hell is empty, and all the devils are here!"

paragraphs.original:
Why, that's my spirit!
But was not this nigh shore?
paragraphs.translated: Good job! But was this near the shore?

paragraphs.original: Close by, my master.
paragraphs.translated: Very near, my master.

paragraphs.original: But are they, Ariel, safe?
paragraphs.translated: But are they all safe, Ariel?

paragraphs.original:
Not a hair perished.
On their sustaining garments not a blemish,
But fresher than before. And, as thou badest me,
In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.
The king's son have I landed by himself,
Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs
In an odd angle of the isle, and sitting,
His arms in this sad knot.
paragraphs.translated:
Nobody was hurt in the slightest. Even their clothes are unstained, and look fresher than before the storm. I've separated them into groups around the island, just as you ordered. I sent the king's son off by himself to a faraway nook on the island, where he's sitting now sighing, with his arms crossed like this. (he folds his arms.)
he folds his arms

paragraphs.original:
Of the king's ship,
The mariners, say how thou hast disposed,
And all the rest o' th' fleet.
paragraphs.translated: Tell me what you did with the king's ship, the sailors, and the other ships.

paragraphs.original:
Safely in harbor
Is the king's ship. In the deep nook where once
Thou called'st me up at midnight to fetch dew
From the still-vexed Bermoothes, there she's hid.
paragraphs.translated: The king's ship is safely in the harbor, hidden in that deep cove where you once summoned me to bring back dew from the stormy Bermuda islands.

paragraphs.original:
The mariners all under hatches stowed,
Who, with a charm joined to their suffered labor,
I have left asleep. And for the rest o' th' fleet,
Which I dispersed, they all have met again
And are upon the Mediterranean float,
Bound sadly home for Naples,
Supposing that they saw the king's ship wracked
And his great person perish.
paragraphs.translated: The sailors are all below deck, sleeping both from their labor and from a magic spell I cast over them. As for the rest of the ships, I scattered them, and they've gathered again in the Mediterranean, sailing sadly home to Naples, believing that they witnessed the shipwreck and death of their great king.

paragraphs.original:
Ariel, thy charge
Exactly is performed. But there's more work.
What is the time o' th' day?
paragraphs.translated: Ariel, you've done your work exactly as I ordered. But there's more work to be done. What time is it?

paragraphs.original: Past the mid season.
paragraphs.translated: Past noon.

paragraphs.original:
At least two glasses. The time 'twixt six and now
Must by us both be spent most preciously.
paragraphs.translated: At least two hours past. We can't waste time between now and six o'clock.

paragraphs.original:
Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains,
Let me remember thee what thou hast promised,
Which is not yet performed me.
paragraphs.translated: Is there more work to do? Since you're giving me new assignments, let me remind you what you promised me but haven't come through with yet.

paragraphs.original:
How now? Moody?
What is 't thou canst demand?
paragraphs.translated: What? You're in a bad mood? What could you possibly ask for?

paragraphs.original: My liberty.
paragraphs.translated: My freedom.

paragraphs.original: Before the time be out? No more!
paragraphs.translated: Before your sentence has been completed? Don't say anything else.

paragraphs.original:
I prithee,
Remember I have done thee worthy service,
Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served
Without or grudge or grumblings. Thou didst promise
To bate me a full year.
paragraphs.translated: I beg you, remember the good work I've done for you, and how I've never lied to you, never made mistakes, and never grumbled in my work. You promised to take a full year off my sentence.

paragraphs.original:
Dost thou forget
From what a torment I did free thee?
paragraphs.translated: Have you forgotten the torture I freed you from?

paragraphs.original: No.
paragraphs.translated: No.

paragraphs.original:
Thou dost, and think'st it much to tread the ooze
Of the salt deep,
To run upon the sharp wind of the north,
To do me business in the veins o' th' earth
When it is baked with frost.
paragraphs.translated: You have forgotten, and you think it's a burden when I ask you to walk through the ocean, or run on the north wind, or do business for me underground when the earth's frozen solid.

paragraphs.original: I do not, sir.
paragraphs.translated: No, I don't, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgot
The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy
Was grown into a hoop? Hast thou forgot her?
paragraphs.translated: You lie, you nasty, ungrateful thing! Have you forgotten the horrid witch Sycorax, stooped over with old age and ill will? Have you forgotten her?

paragraphs.original: No, sir.
paragraphs.translated: No, sir.

paragraphs.original: Thou hast. Where was she born? Speak. Tell me.
paragraphs.translated: You have. Where was she born? Speak. Tell me.

paragraphs.original: Sir, in Argier.
paragraphs.translated: In Algiers, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, was she so? I must
Once in a month recount what thou hast been,
Which thou forget'st. This damned witch Sycorax,
For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible
To enter human hearing, from Argier,
Thou know'st, was banished. For one thing she did
They would not take her life. Is not this true?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, was she now? I'll have to tell the story again every month, since you seem to forget it. This damned witch Sycorax was kicked out of Algiers for various witching crimes too terrible for humans to hear about. But for one reason they refused to execute her. Isn't that true?

paragraphs.original: Ay, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir.

paragraphs.original:
This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child
And here was left by th' sailors. Thou, my slave,
As thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant.
And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate
To act her earthy and abhorred commands,
Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee,
By help of her more potent ministers
And in her most unmitigable rage,
Into a cloven pine, within which rift
Imprisoned thou didst painfully remain
A dozen years; within which space she died
And left thee there, where thou didst vent thy groans
As fast as mill wheels strike. Then was this island - 
Save for the son that she did litter here,
A freckled whelp hag-born - not honored with
A human shape.
paragraphs.translated:
This sunken-eyed hag was brought here pregnant and left by the sailors. You, my slave, were her servant at the time, as you admit yourself. You were too delicate to carry out her horrible orders, and you refused. In a fit of rage she locked you up in a hollow pine tree, with the help of her powerful assistants, and left you there for twelve years. During that time she died, and you were trapped, moaning and groaning as fast as the blades of a
mill wheel strike the water. At that time there were no people here. This island was not honored with a human being - except for the son that Sycorax gave birth to here, a freckled baby born of an old hag.
mill

paragraphs.original: Yes, Caliban, her son.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Caliban, her son.

paragraphs.original:
Dull thing, I say so. He, that Caliban
Whom now I keep in service. Thou best know'st
What torment I did find thee in. Thy groans
Of ever angry bears. It was a torment
Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts
To lay upon the damned, which Sycorax
Could not again undo. It was mine art,
When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape
The pine and let thee out.
paragraphs.translated: That's right, you stupid thing. Caliban, who now serves me. You know better than anyone how tortured you were when I found you. Your groans made wolves howl, and even made bears feel sorry for you. Nobody but the damned souls of hell deserves the spell that Sycorax put on you and couldn't undo. It was my magic that saved you when I arrived on the island and heard you, making the pine tree open and let you out.

paragraphs.original: I thank thee, master.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, master.

paragraphs.original:
If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an oak
And peg thee in his knotty entrails till
Thou hast howled away twelve winters.
paragraphs.translated: If you complain any more, I'll split an oak tree and lock you up in it till you've howled for twelve years.

paragraphs.original:
Pardon, master.
I will be correspondent to command
And do my spiriting gently.
paragraphs.translated: Please forgive me, master. I'll be obedient and do all my tasks without complaining.

paragraphs.original:
Do so, and after two days
I will discharge thee.
paragraphs.translated: Do that, and I'll set you free in two days.

paragraphs.original:
That's my noble master!
What shall I do? Say, what? What shall I do?
paragraphs.translated: That's noble of you, master. What shall I do for you? Just tell me. What shall I do?

paragraphs.original:
Go make thyself like a nymph o' th' sea. Be subject
To no sight but thine and mine, invisible
To every eyeball else. Go take this shape
And hither come in 't. Go hence with diligence.
paragraphs.translated: Go disguise yourself as a sea nymph. Be invisible to everyone except yourself and me. Take this garment, put it on, and then come back here. Hurry, go!

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.

paragraphs.original:
(to MIRANDA)
(to
)
Awake, dear heart, awake! Thou hast slept well.
Awake!

(waking) The strangeness of your story put
(waking)
Heaviness in me.
paragraphs.translated:
(waking up)Your strange story made me groggy.
(waking up)

paragraphs.original:
Shake it off. Come on.
We'll visit Caliban, my slave who never
Yields us kind answer.
paragraphs.translated: Shake off your sleepiness. Come on. We'll go visit Caliban, my slave who always talks to us so nastily.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis a villain, sir,
I do not love to look on.
paragraphs.translated:
He's an evil one, father. I don't like him.
He's

paragraphs.original:
But as 'tis,
We cannot miss him. He does make our fire,
Fetch in our wood, and serves in offices
That profit us. - What, ho! Slave! Caliban!
Thou earth, thou! Speak.
paragraphs.translated: But even so, we can't do without him. He builds our fires, gets our firewood, and does all kinds of useful things for us. - Hey! Caliban! Pile of dirt! Say something.

paragraphs.original:
(within)    There's wood enough within.
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) You've got enough firewood already.
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
Come forth, I say! There's other business for thee.
Come, thou tortoise! When?
paragraphs.translated: Come out, I order you. There's other work for you to do. Come on, you turtle!

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, like a water nymph
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters disguised as a water nymph.

paragraphs.original:
Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel,
Hark in thine ear. (whispers to ARIEL)
(whispers to
)
My lord it shall be done.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I'll do it right away.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.

paragraphs.original:
(to CALIBAN) Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself
(to
)
Upon thy wicked dam, come forth!
Enter CALIBAN
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN enters.

paragraphs.original:
As wicked dew as e'er my mother brushed
With raven's feather from unwholesome fen
Drop on you both! A southwest blow on ye
And blister you all o'er!
paragraphs.translated: I hope you both get drenched with a dew as evil as what my mother used to collect with a crow's feather from the poison swamps. May a hot southwest wind blow on you and cover you with blisters all over.

paragraphs.original:
For this, be sure, tonight thou shalt have cramps,
Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up. Urchins
Shall, forth at vast of night that they may work,
All exercise on thee. Thou shalt be pinched
As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging
Than bees that made 'em.
paragraphs.translated: I'll give you cramps for saying that - horrible pains in your sides that will keep you from breathing. I'll send goblins out at night to work their nasty deeds on you. You'll be pricked all over, and it'll sting like bees.

paragraphs.original:
I must eat my dinner.
This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother,
Which thou takest from me. When thou camest first,
Thou strok'st me and made much of me, wouldst give me
Water with berries in 't, and teach me how
To name the bigger light, and how the less,
That burn by day and night. And then I loved thee
And showed thee all the qualities o' th' isle,
The fresh springs, brine pits, barren place and fertile.
Cursed be I that did so! All the charms
Of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you!
For I am all the subjects that you have,
Which first was mine own king. And here you sty me
In this hard rock, whiles you do keep from me
The rest o' th' island.
paragraphs.translated: I have to eat my dinner now. This island belongs to me because Sycorax, my mother, left it to me. But you've taken it from me. When you first got here, you petted me and took care of me, you would give me water with berries in it, and you taught me the names for the sun and the moon, the big light and the smaller light that burn in daytime and nighttime. I loved you back then. I showed you all the features of the island, the freshwater springs, the saltwater pits, the barren places and the fertile ones. I curse myself for doing that! I wish I could use all the magic spells of Sycorax against you and plague you with toads, beetles, and bats. I'm the only subject you have in your kingdom, and you were my first king, and you pen me up in this cave and don't let me go anywhere else on the island.

paragraphs.original:
Thou most lying slave,
Whom stripes may move, not kindness! I have used thee,
Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee
In mine own cell till thou didst seek to violate
The honor of my child.
paragraphs.translated: You liar, you respond better to the whip than to kindness! I took good care of you - piece of filth that you are - and let you stay in my own hut until you tried to rape my daughter.

paragraphs.original:
Oh ho, oh ho! Would 't had been done!
Thou didst prevent me. I had peopled else
This isle with Calibans.
paragraphs.translated: Oh ho, oh ho! I wish I had! You stopped me. If you hadn't, I would have filled this island with a race of Calibans.

paragraphs.original:
Abhorrèd slave,
Which any print of goodness wilt not take,
Being capable of all ill! I pitied thee,
Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour
One thing or other. When thou didst not, savage,
Know thine own meaning, but wouldst gabble like
A thing most brutish, I endowed thy purposes
With words that made them known. But thy vile race,
Though thou didst learn, had that in 't which good natures
Could not abide to be with. Therefore wast thou
Deservedly confined into this rock,
Who hadst deserved more than a prison.
paragraphs.translated: You horrid slave, you can't be trained to be good, and you're capable of anything evil! I pitied you, worked hard to teach you to speak, and taught you some new thing practically every hour. When you didn't know what you were saying, and were babbling like an animal, I helped you find words to make your point understandable. But you had bad blood in you, no matter how much you learned, and good people couldn't stand to be near you. So you got what you deserved, and were locked up in this cave, which is more fitting for the likes of you than a prison would be.

paragraphs.original:
You taught me language, and my profit on 't
Is I know how to curse. The red plague rid you
For learning me your language!
paragraphs.translated: You taught me language, and all I can do with it is curse. Damn you for teaching me your language!

paragraphs.original:
Hag-seed, hence!
Fetch us in fuel. And be quick, thou 'rt best,
To answer other business. Shrug'st thou, malice?
If thou neglect'st or dost unwillingly
What I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps,
Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar
That beasts shall tremble at thy din.
paragraphs.translated: Get out of here, you son of a bitch! Bring us wood, and be quick about it. Are you shrugging and making faces, you evil thing? If you neglect my orders or do them grudgingly, I'll double you up with pains and cramps, and make all your bones ache, and make you scream so loud that the wild animals will tremble when they hear you.

paragraphs.original:
No, pray thee.
(aside) I must obey. His art is of such power,
(aside)
It would control my dam's god, Setebos,
And make a vassal of him.
paragraphs.translated:
No, please. (to himself) I have to obey. He's got such strong magic powers that he could conquer and enslave the god, Setebos, that my mother used to worship.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: So, slave, hence!
paragraphs.translated: Go then, slave.

paragraphs.original: Exit CALIBAN
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter FERDINAND and ARIEL, invisible, playing and singing
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND enters with ARIEL, who is invisible and playing music and singing.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
Come unto these yellow sands,
Come unto these yellow sands
And then take hands.
And then take hands
Curtsied when you have, and kissed
Curtsied when you have, and kissed
The wild waves whist.
The wild waves whist
Foot it featly here and there,
Foot it featly here and there
And, sweet sprites, bear
And, sweet sprites, bear
The burden. Hark, hark!
The burden. Hark, hark!
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
singing
Come onto these yellow sands,
Come onto these yellow sands
And we'll join hands,
And we'll join hands
When you've curtsied and kissed
When you've curtsied and kissed
The waves into silence.
The waves into silence
Prance lightly here and there,
Prance lightly here and there
And the sweet spirits bear
And the sweet spirits bear
The burden. Listen, listen!
The burden. Listen, listen!

paragraphs.original:
(dispersedly, within) Bow-wow.
(dispersedly, within)
paragraphs.translated:
(refrain of the song is heard offstage, from different places, not in unison) Bow-wow.
(refrain of the song is heard offstage, from different places, not in unison)

paragraphs.original: The watchdogs bark.
paragraphs.translated: The watchdogs bark.

paragraphs.original:
(within) Bow-wow.
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Bow-wow.
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
Hark, hark! I hear
The strain of strutting chanticleer
Cry "Cock-a-diddle-dow."
paragraphs.translated:
Listen, listen! I hear
The tune of the strutting rooster
Who cries cock-a-doodle-doo.

paragraphs.original:
Where should this music be? I' th' air or th' earth?
It sounds no more, and sure, it waits upon
Some god o' th' island. Sitting on a bank,
Weeping again the king my father's wrack,
This music crept by me upon the waters,
Allaying both their fury and my passion
With its sweet air. Thence I have followed it,
Or it hath drawn me rather. But 'tis gone.
No, it begins again.
paragraphs.translated: Where's that music coming from? From the earth, or the air? It's stopped now - it must be played for some local god of the island. As I sat on the shore crying over my father's shipwreck, I heard the music creep over the wild waves, calming their fury and soothing my own grief with its sweet melodies. I followed it here, or I should say it dragged me here. But now it's stopped. No, there it is again.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
Full fathom five thy father lies.
Full fathom five thy father lies
Of his bones are coral made.
Of his bones are coral made
Those are pearls that were his eyes.
Those are pearls that were his eyes
Nothing of him that doth fade,
Nothing of him that doth fade
But doth suffer a sea-change
But doth suffer a sea-change
Into something rich and strange.
Into something rich and strange
Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell
Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
(singing)
Your father lies five whole
fathoms below,
Your father lies five whole
fathoms below
fathoms



His bones have turned to coral now.
His bones have turned to coral now
His eyes have turned to pearls.
His eyes have turned to pearls
There's nothing left of him,
There's nothing left of him
He's undergone a complete sea change
He's undergone a complete sea change
And become something rich and strange.
And become something rich and strange
Sea nymphs ring his death bell every hour.
Sea nymphs ring his death bell every hour

paragraphs.original:
(within) Ding-dong.
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(refrain, offstage)Ding-dong.
refrain, offstage

paragraphs.original: Hark, now I hear them.
paragraphs.translated: Listen, I hear them.

paragraphs.original:
(within)  Ding-dong, bell.
(within)
paragraphs.translated: Ding dong, bell.

paragraphs.original:
The ditty does remember my drowned father.
This is no mortal business, nor no sound
That the earth owes. I hear it now above me.
paragraphs.translated: This song's about my dead father. It couldn't be sung by mere mortals. I hear it now overhead.

paragraphs.original:
(to MIRANDA) The fringèd curtains of thine eye advance
(to
)
And say what thou seest yond.

What is 't? A spirit?
Lord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir,
It carries a brave form. But 'tis a spirit.
paragraphs.translated: What is it? A spirit? Lord, it's glancing every which way! How handsome it is. It must be a spirit.

paragraphs.original:
No, wench! It eats and sleeps and hath such senses
As we have, such. This gallant which thou seest
Was in the wrack. And, but he's something stained
With grief that's beauty's canker, thou mightst call him
A goodly person. He hath lost his fellows
And strays about to find 'em.
paragraphs.translated: No, girl! It eats and sleeps and has the same five senses we do. The gentleman you see now was in the shipwreck, and if he weren't a little spoiled by grief, which always ruins good looks, you could call him handsome. He's lost his comrades and is wandering around looking for them.

paragraphs.original:
I might call him
A thing divine, for nothing natural
I ever saw so noble.
paragraphs.translated: I could imagine he's divine, since I never saw anything so noble-looking on earth before.

paragraphs.original:
(aside)    It goes on, I see,
(aside)
As my soul prompts it. - Spirit, fine spirit! I'll free thee
Within two days for this.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) It's all happening according to plan, just as my soul wanted it to happen. (to ARIEL) Spirit, you fine spirit, I'll set you free in two days for doing such a good job here.
(to himself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
(seeing MIRANDA)  Most sure, the goddess
(seeing
)
On whom these airs attend! - Vouchsafe my prayer
May know if you remain upon this island,
And that you will some good instruction give
How I may bear me here. My prime request,
Which I do last pronounce, is - O you wonder! - 
If you be maid or no.

No wonder, sir,
But certainly a maid.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not marvelous, sir, but I'm certainly a maiden.

paragraphs.original:
My language! Heavens,
I am the best of them that speak this speech,
Were I but where 'tis spoken.
paragraphs.translated: She speaks my language! My God, I'm the highest-ranking person who speaks this language - if only we were back where it's spoken.

paragraphs.original:
How? The best?
What wert thou if the King of Naples heard thee?
paragraphs.translated: What's that? The highest-ranking? What would the King of Naples do if he heard you say that?

paragraphs.original:
A single thing, as I am now, that wonders
To hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me,
And that he does I weep. Myself am Naples,
Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld
The king my father wracked.
paragraphs.translated: He would just see me for what I am, a person amazed to hear you talking about Naples. He does hear me, and that makes me cry. I myself am the King of Naples, since I saw with my own eyes - these eyes that haven't been dry since - my father killed in a shipwreck.

paragraphs.original: Alack, for mercy!
paragraphs.translated: Ah, how pitiful!

paragraphs.original:
Yes, faith, and all his lords, the Duke of Milan
And his brave son being twain.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, indeed, and all the King's men, the Duke of Milan and his fine son too.

paragraphs.original:
(aside)   The Duke of Milan
(aside)
And his more braver daughter could control thee
If now 'twere fit to do 't! At the first sight
They have changed eyes. - Delicate Ariel,
I'll set thee free for this.
(to FERDINAND)
(to
)
A word, good sir.
I fear you have done yourself some wrong. A word.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) The real Duke of Milan and his far finer daughter could beat you in a heartbeat, if it were the right time. They've fallen in love at first sight! - Wonderful Ariel, I'll set you free for doing such good work here. (to FERDINAND) Could I have a word with you, sir? I'm afraid you've made a mistake. Just a word.
(to himself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Why speaks my father so ungently? This
(aside)
Is the third man that e'er I saw, the first
That e'er I sighed for. Pity move my father
To be inclined my way!
paragraphs.translated:
(to herself) Why is my father speaking to him so rudely? This is the third man I've ever seen in my life, and the first one I've felt romantic feelings for. I hope my father takes pity on me and treats him well for my sake!
(to herself)

paragraphs.original:
(to MIRANDA)
(to
)
Oh, if a virgin,
And your affection not gone forth, I'll make you
The queen of Naples.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, if you're a virgin, and you haven't given your heart to another man, then I'll make you the queen of Naples.

paragraphs.original:
Soft, sir! One word more.
(aside)
(aside)
They are both in either's powers, but this swift business
I must uneasy make lest too light winning
Make the prize light.
(to FERDINAND)
(to
)
One word more. I charge thee
That thou attend me. Thou dost here usurp
The name thou owest not, and hast put thyself
Upon this island as a spy to win it
From me, the lord on 't.
paragraphs.translated:
Hang on, sir! Just a moment. (to himself) They're both in love. But I need to cause a little trouble between them, or else they'll never appreciate the value of their love. (to FERDINAND) I need a word with you, sir. I order you to listen to me. You're calling yourself by a name that doesn't belong to you. You've come onto this island as a spy, to snatch it away from me - I'm the rightful lord of it.
(to himself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original: No, as I am a man!
paragraphs.translated: No, I swear, that's not true!

paragraphs.original:
There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple.
If the ill spirit have so fair a house,
Good things will strive to dwell with 't.
paragraphs.translated: A man as handsome as that can't have anything evil in him. If the devil had such a beautiful house as his body, then good things would fight to live in it.

paragraphs.original:
(to FERDINAND)   Follow me.
(to
)
(to MIRANDA) Speak not you for him. He's a traitor.
(to
)
(to FERDINAND)    Come,
(to
)
I'll manacle thy neck and feet together.
Seawater shalt thou drink. Thy food shall be
The fresh-brook mussles, withered roots, and husks
Wherein the acorn cradled. Follow.

No.
I will resist such entertainment till
Mine enemy has more power.
paragraphs.translated: No, I'll have to decline that offer - at least as long as I'm stronger than you are.

paragraphs.original: FERDINAND draws his sword, and is charmed from moving
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND takes out his sword, but PROSPERO casts a spell on him that freezes him in place.

paragraphs.original:
O dear father,
Make not too rash a trial of him, for
He's gentle and not fearful.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, dear father, don't judge him too quickly. He's a good man, and brave too.

paragraphs.original:
What, I say?
My foot my tutor? - Put thy sword up, traitor,
Who makest a show but darest not strike, thy conscience
Is so possessed with guilt. Come from thy ward,
For I can here disarm thee with this stick
And make thy weapon drop.
paragraphs.translated: What's that? The daughter knows more than the father? - Put away your sword, traitor. You make quite a show there, but you're too scared to strike at me, since you feel too guilty. Get out of that position, because I can disarm you with my magic wand and make your sword drop.

paragraphs.original: Beseech you, father.
paragraphs.translated: Please, father, I beg you.

paragraphs.original: Hence! Hang not on my garments.
paragraphs.translated: Let go of me! Don't tug on my clothes.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, have pity,
I'll be his surety.
paragraphs.translated: Father, take pity on him. I'll guarantee his goodness myself.

paragraphs.original:
Silence! One word more
Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee. What,
An advocate for an imposter? Hush,
Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he,
Having seen but him and Caliban. Foolish wench,
To th' most of men this is a Caliban
And they to him are angels.
paragraphs.translated: Quiet! If you say one more word, I'll punish you, maybe even hate you. You're defending an impostor? Be quiet. You think he's special, since you've only ever seen him and Caliban. Foolish girl, in the eyes of most people this man's a Caliban, and compared to him, they're angels.

paragraphs.original:
My affections
Are then most humble. I have no ambition
To see a goodlier man.
paragraphs.translated: Then my love is humble. I don't feel any urge to see a more handsome man than this one.

paragraphs.original:
(to FERDINAND)   Come on. Obey.
(to
)
Thy nerves are in their infancy again
And have no vigor in them.

So they are.
My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
My father's loss, the weakness which I feel,
The wrack of all my friends, nor this man's threats,
To whom I am subdued, are but light to me,
Might I but through my prison once a day
Behold this maid. All corners else o' th' earth
Let liberty make use of. Space enough
Have I in such a prison.
paragraphs.translated: That's true, they are. My strength is all gone, as if in a dream. The death of my father, my physical weakness, the loss of all my friends, the threats of this man who's taken me prisoner - all that would be easy for me to take, if only I could look through my prison windows once a day and see this girl. I don't need any more freedom than that. A prison like that would give me enough liberty.

paragraphs.original:
(aside)  It works!
(aside)
(to FERDINAND)    Come on.
(to
)
(aside) Thou hast done well, fine Ariel!
(aside)
(to FERDINAND)    Follow me.
(to
)
(to ARIEL) Hark what thou else shalt do me.
(to
)

(to FERDINAND)  Be of comfort.
(to
)
My father's of a better nature, sir,
Than he appears by speech. This is unwonted
Which now came from him.

(to ARIEL)  Thou shalt be free
(to
)
As mountain winds. But then exactly do
All points of my command.
To th' syllable.
paragraphs.translated: Down to the last detail.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, GONZALO, ADRIAN, FRANCISCO, and others
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, GONZALO, ADRIAN, FRANCISCO, and others enter.

paragraphs.original:
(to ALONSO)
(to
)
Beseech you, sir, be merry. You have cause,
So have we all, of joy, for our escape
Is much beyond our loss. Our hint of woe
Is common. Every day some sailor's wife,
The masters of some merchant, and the merchant
Have just our theme of woe. But for the miracle - 
I mean our preservation - few in millions
Can speak like us. Then wisely, good sir, weigh
Our sorrow with our comfort.
Prithee, peace.
paragraphs.translated: Please say no more.

paragraphs.original: Look he's winding up the watch of his wit. By and by it will strike.

When every grief is entertained that's offered,
Comes to th' entertainer -
paragraphs.translated: If we let every sad thing that happens to us get us down, then we would find ourselves -

paragraphs.original: A dollar.
paragraphs.translated: What a pain.

paragraphs.original: Dolor comes to him, indeed. You have spoken truer than you purposed.
paragraphs.translated: Pain, yes indeed. We would find ourselves in pain. You thought you were being funny, but you said the truth.

paragraphs.original: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.
paragraphs.translated: You're taking it more seriously than I meant it.

paragraphs.original: Well, I have done. But yet -
paragraphs.translated: Well, I'm nearly finished. But just one last thing -

paragraphs.original: Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?
paragraphs.translated: Hey, let's bet. Which one will start yammering first, Gonzalo or Adrian?

paragraphs.original: The old cock.
paragraphs.translated: The old guy.

paragraphs.original: The cockerel.
paragraphs.translated: I pick the younger one.

paragraphs.original: Done. The wager?
paragraphs.translated: You're on. What's the prize?

paragraphs.original: A laughter.
paragraphs.translated: A good laugh.

paragraphs.original: A match!
paragraphs.translated: It's a deal!

paragraphs.original: Though this island seem to be desert -
paragraphs.translated: Though this island may appear desolate -

paragraphs.original: So you're paid.
paragraphs.translated: Fine, you win.

paragraphs.original: Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible -
paragraphs.translated: Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible, as it were -

paragraphs.original: Yet -
paragraphs.translated: Now he's going to say "but" -

paragraphs.original: Yet -
paragraphs.translated: But -

paragraphs.original: He could not miss 't.
paragraphs.translated: He had to say it, it was unavoidable.

paragraphs.original: It must needs be of subtle, tender, and delicate temperance.
paragraphs.translated: The island must be mild, and have a temperate climate.

paragraphs.original: Temperance was a delicate wench.
paragraphs.translated: I knew Temperance - she was a fine girl.

paragraphs.original: Ay, and a subtle, as he most learnedly delivered.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and she was mild too.

paragraphs.original: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
paragraphs.translated: There's always a breath of fresh air here.

paragraphs.original: As if it had lungs, and rotten ones.
paragraphs.translated: A breath from rotten lungs, maybe.

paragraphs.original: Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.
paragraphs.translated: Stinking like a swamp.

paragraphs.original: Here is everything advantageous to life.
paragraphs.translated: This island contains everything beneficial to life.

paragraphs.original: True. Save means to live.
paragraphs.translated: True. Everything except something to live on.

paragraphs.original: Of that there's none, or little.
paragraphs.translated: There's little or nothing of that.

paragraphs.original: How lush and lusty the grass looks! How green!
paragraphs.translated: Look how lush and healthy the grass is! How green!

paragraphs.original: The ground indeed is tawny.
paragraphs.translated: The ground is brown.

paragraphs.original: With an eye of green in 't.
paragraphs.translated: With a touch of green in it.

paragraphs.original: He misses not much.
paragraphs.translated: He doesn't miss a thing.

paragraphs.original: No, he doth but mistake the truth totally.
paragraphs.translated: No, he just gets reality completely wrong.

paragraphs.original: But the rarity of it is - which is indeed almost beyond credit -
paragraphs.translated: But the really unbelievable thing is - and this is incredible -

paragraphs.original: As many vouched rarities are.
paragraphs.translated: As most unbelievable things are.

paragraphs.original: That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.
paragraphs.translated: That our clothes were drenched with sea water, but they came out looking brand-new.

paragraphs.original: If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?
paragraphs.translated: Listen to him. If his clothes could talk, they'd call him a liar.

paragraphs.original: Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.
paragraphs.translated: Or stuff what he says into their pockets.

paragraphs.original: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
paragraphs.translated: Seriously, I think our clothes are as fresh now as they were the day we put them on in Africa, when we attended the marriage of the king's daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.

paragraphs.original: 'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.
paragraphs.translated: It was a lovely wedding, and we're doing really well on our trip home.

paragraphs.original: Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.
paragraphs.translated: Tunis has never had such a beautiful queen.

paragraphs.original: Not since widow Dido's time.
paragraphs.translated:
Not since the days of widow
Dido.
Dido

paragraphs.original: Widow! A pox o' that! How came that "widow" in? Widow Dido!
paragraphs.translated: Widow? Why the hell is he calling her "widow Dido"?

paragraphs.original: What if he had said "widower Æneas" too? Good Lord, how you take it!
paragraphs.translated: Next thing you know, he'll be saying "widower Aeneas."

paragraphs.original: "Widow Dido" said you? You make me study of that. She was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
paragraphs.translated: "Widow Dido," did you say? I'm not sure about that. Dido was from Carthage, not Tunis.

paragraphs.original: This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.
paragraphs.translated:
Tunis was Carthage, sir.
Tunis



was

paragraphs.original: Carthage?
paragraphs.translated: Carthage?

paragraphs.original: I assure you, Carthage.
paragraphs.translated: I'm telling you, it was Carthage.

paragraphs.original: His word is more than the miraculous harp. He hath raised the wall and houses too.
paragraphs.translated: Gonzalo is a miracle-worker. If he says Carthage was here, then Carthage must be here.

paragraphs.original: What impossible matter will he make easy next?
paragraphs.translated: What miracle will he work next?

paragraphs.original: I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.
paragraphs.translated: I think he'll carry this island home in his pocket and give it to his son like an apple.

paragraphs.original: And sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.
paragraphs.translated: And then throw the seeds in the sea, to make more islands grow.

paragraphs.original: Ay.
paragraphs.translated: Yes indeed.

paragraphs.original: Why, in good time.
paragraphs.translated: Absolutely, yes indeed.

paragraphs.original: And the rarest that e'er came there.
paragraphs.translated: The most beautiful queen they ever had.

paragraphs.original: Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.
paragraphs.translated: I beg your pardon, except for the widow Dido.

paragraphs.original: Oh, widow Dido? Ay, widow Dido.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, except for the widow Dido? That's right, except for the widow Dido.

paragraphs.original: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it? I mean, in a sort.
paragraphs.translated: Isn't my vest just as clean and fresh as the day I put it on? In a way, I mean.

paragraphs.original: That "sort" was well fished for.
paragraphs.translated: "In a way" is the right way to go.

paragraphs.original: When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?
paragraphs.translated: I mean when I wore it at your daughter's wedding.

paragraphs.original:
You cram these words into mine ears against
The stomach of my sense. Would I had never
Married my daughter there! For, coming thence,
My son is lost and, in my rate, she too,
Who is so far from Italy removed
I ne'er again shall see her. - O thou mine heir
Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish
Hath made his meal on thee?
paragraphs.translated: You keep cramming words into my ears that I don't want to hear. I wish that wedding had never happened, since I lost my son because of it, and I lost my daughter too in a way, since she's moved so far from Milan that I'll never see her again. - Oh, dear son of mine and heir of Naples and Milan, what strange fish has made a meal of you?

paragraphs.original:
Sir, he may live.
I saw him beat the surges under him,
And ride upon their backs. He trod the water,
Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted
The surge most swoll'n that met him. His bold head
'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oared
Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke
To th' shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bowed,
As stooping to relieve him. I not doubt
He came alive to land.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, he may still be alive. I saw him swimming strongly, almost as if he was riding the waves. He treaded water and kept his head well above the wild waters coming at him, swimming with his strong arms toward the shore, which almost seemed eager to welcome him. I have no doubt he got ashore alive.

paragraphs.original: No, no, he's gone.
paragraphs.translated: No, no, he's dead.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss,
That would not bless our Europe with your daughter,
But rather loose her to an African,
Where she at least is banished from your eye,
Who hath cause to wet the grief on 't.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, you can thank yourself for this great loss, because you wouldn't bless Europe with your daughter, but instead pimped her out to an African. At least you can be thankful that she won't be around to remind you of your loss.

paragraphs.original: Prithee, peace.
paragraphs.translated: Please be quiet.

paragraphs.original:
You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise
By all of us, and the fair soul herself
Weighed between loathness and obedience, at
Which end o' th' beam should bow. We have lost your son,
I fear, forever. Milan and Naples have
More widows in them of this business' making
Than we bring men to comfort them.
The fault's your own.
paragraphs.translated: We all begged you not to go ahead with those marriage plans, and your lovely daughter struggled between disgust at marrying an African and the desire to obey you. Now I'm afraid we've lost your son forever. Our shipwreck has made more women widows in Milan and Naples than there are survivors to comfort them. And it's all your fault.

paragraphs.original: So is the dearest o' th' loss.
paragraphs.translated: And the greatest sorrow is mine too.

paragraphs.original:
My lord Sebastian,
The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness
And time to speak it in. You rub the sore
When you should bring the plaster.
paragraphs.translated: My lord Sebastian, even though what you say is true, your way of saying it is tactless and comes at the wrong time. You're rubbing salt in his wounds when you should be applying bandages.

paragraphs.original: Very well.
paragraphs.translated: All right, I'll stop.

paragraphs.original: And most chirurgeonly.
paragraphs.translated: Like a good doctor.

paragraphs.original:
(to ALONSO) It is foul weather in us all, good sir,
(to
)
When you are cloudy.
Foul weather?
paragraphs.translated: Bad times?

paragraphs.original: Very foul.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, very bad.

paragraphs.original: Had I plantation of this isle, my lord -
paragraphs.translated: If I could colonize this island, my lord -

paragraphs.original: He'd sow 't with nettle seed.
paragraphs.translated: He'd cultivate weeds on it.

paragraphs.original: Or docks, or mallows.
paragraphs.translated: Or thorn-bushes.

paragraphs.original: And were the king on 't, what would I do?
paragraphs.translated: And if I were king of it, you know what I'd do?

paragraphs.original: 'Scape being drunk for want of wine.
paragraphs.translated: He wouldn't get drunk much, since there's no wine here.

paragraphs.original:
I' th' commonwealth I would by contraries
Execute all things. For no kind of traffic
Would I admit. No name of magistrate.
Letters should not be known. Riches, poverty,
And use of service - none. Contract, succession,
Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard - none.
No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil.
No occupation. All men idle, all.
And women too, but innocent and pure.
No sovereignty -
paragraphs.translated:
In my kingdom I'd do everything differently from the way it's usually done. I wouldn't allow any commerce. There'd be no officials or administrators. There'd be no schooling or literature. There'd be no riches, no poverty, and no servants - none. No contracts or inheritance laws; no division of the land into private farms, no metal-working, agriculture, or vineyards.
There'd be no work. Men would have nothing to do, and women also - but they'd be innocent and pure. There'd be no kingship -

paragraphs.original: Yet he would be king on 't.
paragraphs.translated: He wants to be king in a place with no kingship.

paragraphs.original: The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, he's getting a bit confused.

paragraphs.original:
All things in common nature should produce
Without sweat or endeavor. Treason, felony,
Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine,
Would I not have. But nature should bring forth
Of its own kind all foison, all abundance,
To feed my innocent people.
paragraphs.translated: Everything would be produced without labor, and would be shared by all. There'd be no treason, crimes, or weapons. Nature would produce its harvests in abundance, to feed my innocent people.

paragraphs.original: No marrying 'mong his subjects?
paragraphs.translated: There'd be no marriage?

paragraphs.original: None, man. All idle. Whores and knaves.
paragraphs.translated: No. Everyone would have nothing to do. They'd all be whores and slackers.

paragraphs.original:
I would with such perfection govern, sir,
T' excel the Golden Age.
paragraphs.translated: I would rule so perfectly that my country would outshine the Golden Age they had in ancient times.

paragraphs.original: 'Save his majesty!
paragraphs.translated: Long live his Majesty!

paragraphs.original: Long live Gonzalo!
paragraphs.translated: All hail Gonzalo!

paragraphs.original: Prithee, no more. Thou dost talk nothing to me.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, please be quiet. You're spouting empty words.

paragraphs.original: I do well believe your highness, and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.
paragraphs.translated: You're absolutely right, your highness. I talked like that to give these gentlemen here a chance to have a good laugh. They love to laugh at empty words.

paragraphs.original: 'Twas you we laughed at.
paragraphs.translated: It's you we were laughing at.

paragraphs.original: Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you. So you may continue and laugh at nothing still.
paragraphs.translated: But from your perspective I don't matter, so I'm just an empty nobody for you. Go ahead and laugh at my empty words some more.

paragraphs.original: What a blow was there given!
paragraphs.translated: Ouch, what a comeback!

paragraphs.original: An it had not fallen flat-long.
paragraphs.translated: He sure did. Too bad it fell flat.

paragraphs.original: You are gentlemen of brave mettle. You would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
paragraphs.translated: You're brave gentlemen. You'd give the moon a shove if it got stuck five weeks in its orbit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL invisible, playing solemn music
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, invisible, playing solemn music.

paragraphs.original: We would so, and then go a-batfowling.
paragraphs.translated: That's right, and then after we fixed the moon, we'd go bird-hunting.

paragraphs.original: No, I warrant you. I will not adventure my discretion so weakly. Will you laugh me asleep, for I am very heavy?
paragraphs.translated: I'm not. I've got good judgment, and I know you've got nothing against me. Will you laugh me to sleep? I'm feeling very sleepy.

paragraphs.original: Go sleep, and hear us.
paragraphs.translated: Go to sleep, and listen to us laughing.

paragraphs.original: All sleep except ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, and ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone sleeps except ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, and ANTONIO.

paragraphs.original:
What, all so soon asleep? I wish mine eyes
Would with themselves shut up my thoughts. I find
They are inclined to do so.
paragraphs.translated: What, everybody falls asleep so fast? I wish I could sleep too - it would stop me from thinking. Come to think of it, I am feeling sleepy.

paragraphs.original:
Please you, sir,
Do not omit the heavy offer of it.
It seldom visits sorrow. When it doth,
It is a comforter.
paragraphs.translated: In that case you should sleep. People in grief need a good sleep. It doesn't come to them often, but when it does come they should enjoy it.

paragraphs.original:
We two, my lord,
Will guard your person while you take your rest
And watch your safety.
paragraphs.translated: The two of us will guard you while you sleep, my lord, and keep you safe.

paragraphs.original: Thank you. Wondrous heavy.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you. I'm terribly sleepy.

paragraphs.original: (falls asleep)
