paragraphs.translated: He falls asleep.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.

paragraphs.original: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!
paragraphs.translated: How strange that they all got so sleepy!

paragraphs.original: It is the quality o' th' climate.
paragraphs.translated: There must be something in the air here.

paragraphs.original:
Why
Doth it not then our eyelids sink? I find not
Myself disposed to sleep.
paragraphs.translated: So why aren't our eyelids heavy? I'm not sleepy at all.

paragraphs.original:
Nor I. My spirits are nimble.
They fell together all, as by consent.
They dropped, as by a thunderstroke. What might,
Worthy Sebastian, O, what might - ? No more. - 
And yet methinks I see it in thy face,
What thou shouldst be. Th' occasion speaks thee, and
My strong imagination sees a crown
Dropping upon thy head.
paragraphs.translated: Me neither. I'm wide awake. They all fell asleep together, as if they'd planned it. Like they'd all been struck by lightning. What might happen, Sebastian, what might happen if - No, it's time for me to shut up. -  But still, I think I can see in your face what you ought to be. Opportunity's knocking for you, and in my imagination I see a crown dropping onto your head.

paragraphs.original: What, art thou waking?
paragraphs.translated: Are you dreaming or awake?

paragraphs.original: Do you not hear me speak?
paragraphs.translated: Don't you hear me speaking?

paragraphs.original:
I do, and surely
It is a sleepy language, and thou speak'st
Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say?
This is a strange repose, to be asleep
With eyes wide open, standing, speaking, moving,
And yet so fast asleep.
paragraphs.translated: I do, and it sounds like you're talking in your sleep. What did you say? It's weird for you to be dreaming with your eyes wide open - standing, talking, moving, but sound asleep.

paragraphs.original:
Noble Sebastian,
Thou let'st thy fortune sleep - die, rather - wink'st
Whiles thou art waking.
paragraphs.translated: Good Sebastian, you're the one who's sleeping if you let this opportunity pass you by without acting on it.

paragraphs.original:
Thou dost snore distinctly.
There's meaning in thy snores.
paragraphs.translated: You're snoring, but it sounds like you're talking. There's meaning in your snoring.

paragraphs.original:
I am more serious than my custom. You
Must be so too if heed me, which to do
Trebles thee o'er.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not kidding when I say this, I'm not joking around like usual. You should be serious too when you listen to what I'm saying. You can become a great man if you listen to me.

paragraphs.original: Well, I am standing water.
paragraphs.translated: I'm hanging on every word you say.

paragraphs.original: I'll teach you how to flow.
paragraphs.translated: You need to do more than hang around - you have to act. I'll show you how.

paragraphs.original:
Do so. To ebb
Hereditary sloth instructs me.
paragraphs.translated: You need to. I'm lazy by nature.

paragraphs.original:
Oh,
If you but knew how you the purpose cherish
Whiles thus you mock it! How, in stripping it,
You more invest it! Ebbing men indeed
Most often do so near the bottom run
By their own fear or sloth.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, if you only knew how close to success you are, even while you make fun of what I'm telling you! The more you joke about it, the more clearly I feel how serious it is! Lazy people end up at the bottom, and you deserve to be at the top.

paragraphs.original:
Prithee, say on.
The setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim
A matter from thee, and a birth indeed
Which throes thee much to yield.
paragraphs.translated: Please, tell me more. There's something in your expression that tells me you have something serious to say, and you're having a lot of difficulty saying it.

paragraphs.original:
Thus, sir:
Although this lord of weak remembrance - this,
Who shall be of as little memory
When he is earthed - hath here almost persuade
(For he's a spirit of persuasion only,
Professes to persuade) the king his son's alive,
'Tis as impossible that he's undrowned
And he that sleeps here swims.

I have no hope
That he's undrowned.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I'm sure he's dead. I've got no hope that he survived.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, out of that "no hope"
What great hope have you! No hope that way is
Another way so high a hope that even
Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond,
But doubt discovery there. Will you grant with me
That Ferdinand is drowned?
paragraphs.translated: But in that "no hope" there are great hopes for you! That "no hope" means you're on the way to glory so brilliant you couldn't even imagine it, no matter how ambitious you were. Do you agree that Ferdinand must have drowned?

paragraphs.original: He's gone.
paragraphs.translated: He's dead.

paragraphs.original:
Then, tell me,
Who's the next heir of Naples?
paragraphs.translated: So, in that case, tell me who's next in line to inherit the kingdom of Naples?

paragraphs.original: Claribel.
paragraphs.translated: Claribel, his daughter.

paragraphs.original:
She that is Queen of Tunis; she that dwells
Ten leagues beyond man's life; she that from Naples
Can have no note, unless the sun were post - 
The man i' th' moon's too slow - till newborn chins
Be rough and razorable; she that from whom
We all were sea-swallowed, though some cast again,
And by that destiny to perform an act
Whereof what's past is prologue, what to come
In yours and my discharge.
paragraphs.translated: The one who's now Queen of Tunis, living at the edge of the world, out of reach of mail service. It takes a letter longer to reach her than it takes a baby boy to grow old enough to shave. Claribel who was the cause of our shipwreck, which a few of us survived - she was destined to give us an opportunity that we are destined to act on.

paragraphs.original:
What stuff is this? How say you?
'Tis true, my brother's daughter's Queen of Tunis,
So is she heir of Naples, 'twixt which regions
There is some space.
paragraphs.translated: What in the world are you talking about? It's true that my brother's daughter is Queen of Tunis, and heir of Naples. And it's true those two places are far apart.

paragraphs.original:
A space whose every cubit
Seems to cry out, "How shall that Claribel
Measure us back to Naples? Keep in Tunis,
paragraphs.translated: So far that every foot of distance between them seems to shout, "It's too far for Claribel to come back to Naples. Let her stay in Tunis and give Sebastian a

paragraphs.original:
And let Sebastian wake." Say this were death
That now hath seized them. Why, they were no worse
Than now they are. There be that can rule Naples
As well as he that sleeps, lords that can prate
As amply and unnecessarily
As this Gonzalo. I myself could make
A chough of as deep chat. Oh, that you bore
The mind that I do, what a sleep were this
For your advancement! Do you understand me?
paragraphs.translated: chance to start living." If these sleeping men were dead instead of sleeping, they'd be no worse off than they are now. There are a lot of men who can rule Naples just as well as this sleeping guy here can. There are a lot of men who babble nonsense as well as Gonzalo. I could do it myself. Oh, I wish you understood what I'm saying - you'd see how you're missing out on a great opportunity for yourself! Do you even get what I'm saying?

paragraphs.original: Methinks I do.
paragraphs.translated: I think I do.

paragraphs.original:
And how does your content
Tender your own good fortune?
paragraphs.translated: And does this prospect of good fortune make you happy?

paragraphs.original:
I remember
You did supplant your brother Prospero.
paragraphs.translated: I remember you took the throne from your brother Prospero.

paragraphs.original:
True.
And look how well my garments sit upon me,
Much feater than before. My brother's servants
Were then my fellows. Now they are my men.
paragraphs.translated: Yes I did, and look how good I look in my new role - much better than before. My brother's servants used to be my equals. Now they work for me.

paragraphs.original: But, for your conscience?
paragraphs.translated: But what about your guilty conscience?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, sir. Where lies that? If 'twere a kibe,
'Twould put me to my slipper. But I feel not
This deity in my bosom. Twenty consciences,
That stand 'twixt me and Milan, candied be they
And melt ere they molest! Here lies your brother,
No better than the earth he lies upon,
If he were that which now he's like - that's dead - 
Whom I, with this obedient steel, three inches of it,
Can lay to bed for ever; whiles you, doing thus,
To the perpetual wink for aye might put
This ancient morsel, this Sir Prudence, who
paragraphs.translated: Yes. What guilty conscience? I don't feel anything. If my feet were cold, I'd put my slippers on, but I don't feel any pangs of guilt. If there were twenty guilty consciences between me and the dukedom, they'd melt away to nothing before they caused me any trouble. Here's your brother sleeping, worth no more than the dirt he's lying on. If he were as dead as he appears to be now - and I could quickly make him dead with this sword of mine - he wouldn't stand in our way. As

paragraphs.original:
Should not upbraid our course. For all the rest,
They'll take suggestion as a cat laps milk.
They'll tell the clock to any business that
We say befits the hour.
paragraphs.translated: for the other men, we can make them believe anything we choose. They'll set their watches to whatever time we say.

paragraphs.original:
Thy case, dear friend,
Shall be my precedent. As thou got'st Milan,
I'll come by Naples. Draw thy sword. One stroke
Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest.
And I the king shall love thee.
paragraphs.translated: You'll be my role model. Just as you got Milan, I'll get Naples. Take out your sword. With one cut you can be through paying money to Naples. And as king I'll love you forever.

paragraphs.original:
Draw together.
And when I rear my hand, do you the like,
To fall it on Gonzalo.
paragraphs.translated: You take out your sword too. When I raise my hand, you do the same, and bring it down on Gonzalo's head.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN draw their swords
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN take out their swords.

paragraphs.original:
O, but one word.
(speaks quietly to ANTONIO)
(speaks quietly to
)
Enter ARIEL invisible, with music and song
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, invisible, singing and playing music.

paragraphs.original:
(to GONZALO) My master through his art foresees the danger
(to
)
That you, his friend, are, and sends me forth - 
For else his project dies - to keep them living.
(sings in GONZALO 's ear)
(sings in
's ear)
While you here do snoring lie,
While you here do snoring lie
Open-eyed conspiracy
Open-eyed conspiracy
His time doth take.
His time doth take
If of life you keep a care,
If of life you keep a care
Shake off slumber and beware.
Shake off slumber and beware
Awake, awake!
Awake, awake!
paragraphs.translated:
(to GONZALO) With his magic powers my master can see the dangers that you are in, my friend. So he sent me to make sure these men survive - and to guarantee his plans succeed. (sings in GONZALO 's ear)
(to
)
(sings in
's ear)
While you lie here snoring,
While you lie here snoring,
Men are plotting against you.
Men are plotting against you.
If you want to stay alive,
If you want to stay alive,
Wake up and beware.
Wake up and beware.
Wake up, wake up!
Wake up, wake up!

paragraphs.original: Then let us both be sudden.
paragraphs.translated: Let's act quickly.

paragraphs.original:
(waking and seeing them)
(waking and seeing them)
Now, good angels preserve the king!
paragraphs.translated:
(waking and seeing them) God help the king! Save him!
(waking and seeing them)

paragraphs.original:
(waking) Why, how now? Ho, awake!
(waking)
paragraphs.translated:
(waking up) Hey, what's this, what's going on? Wake up!
(waking up)

paragraphs.original: All wake
paragraphs.translated: Everyone wakes up.

paragraphs.original:
Why are you drawn?
Wherefore this ghastly looking?
paragraphs.translated: Why are your swords out? Why do you look like that?

paragraphs.original: What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's this all about?

paragraphs.original:
Whiles we stood here securing your repose,
Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing
Like bulls, or rather lions. Did 't not wake you?
It struck mine ear most terribly.
paragraphs.translated: While we were here guarding you as you slept, we heard a loud roar that sounded like bulls, or lions. Didn't you hear it? We heard it very clearly.

paragraphs.original: I heard nothing.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't hear anything.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, 'twas a din to fright a monster's ear,
To make an earthquake! Sure, it was the roar
Of a whole herd of lions.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, it was a monstrous roar, to make the earth tremble! I'm sure there was a herd of lions nearby.

paragraphs.original: Heard you this, Gonzalo?
paragraphs.translated: Did you hear this, Gonzalo?

paragraphs.original:
Upon mine honor, sir, I heard a humming,
And that a strange one too, which did awake me.
I shaked you, sir, and cried. As mine eyes opened,
I saw their weapons drawn. There was a noise,
That's verily. 'Tis best we stand upon our guard,
Or that we quit this place. Let's draw our weapons.
paragraphs.translated: It's true I heard a humming sound, a strange one, which woke me up. I shook you and shouted at you, sir. When I opened my eyes, I saw their swords out. There was a noise, that's certainly true. We should either be on guard here constantly or move to a different camp. Let's draw our own swords too.

paragraphs.original:
Lead off this ground, and let's make further search
For my poor son.
paragraphs.translated: Lead us away from this area. We can search for my poor son while we're at it.

paragraphs.original:
Heavens keep him from these beasts!
For he is, sure, i' th' island.
paragraphs.translated: I hope those lions stay far away from him. I'm sure he's somewhere on the island.

paragraphs.original: Lead away.
paragraphs.translated: Get us out of here.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Prospero my lord shall know what I have done.
(aside)
So, King, go safely on to seek thy son.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) My lord Prospero will know what I've done. So go ahead, King, and look for your son.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CALIBAN with a burden of wood A noise of thunder heard
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN enters with a load of wood. A noise of thunder is heard.

paragraphs.original:
All the infections that the sun sucks up
From bogs, fens, flats, on Prosper fall and make him
By inchmeal a disease! His spirits hear me
And yet I needs must curse. But they'll nor pinch,
Fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' th' mire,
Nor lead me like a firebrand in the dark
Out of my way, unless he bid 'em. But
For every trifle are they set upon me,
Sometime like apes that mow and chatter at me,
And after bite me, then like hedgehogs which
Lie tumbling in my barefoot way and mount
Their pricks at my footfall. Sometime am I
All wound with adders who with cloven tongues
Do hiss me into madness.
paragraphs.translated: I hope all the diseases that breed in swamps and marshes infect Prospero, inch by inch, until he's nothing but a walking disease! His spirits are listening to me, but I can't help cursing him anyway. They won't pinch me, frighten me, push me in the mud, or mislead me unless he tells them to. But he sends them to punish me for every little thing. Sometimes his spirits take the form of apes, grimacing and chattering at me and then biting me; sometimes they come like porcupines, my feet as I walk. Sometimes snakes wrap around me, hissing at me with their forked tongues till I go crazy.

paragraphs.original: Enter TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO enters.

paragraphs.original:
Lo, now, lo!
Here comes a spirit of his, and to torment me
For bringing wood in slowly. I'll fall flat.
Perchance he will not mind me.
(lies down, covered by his gaberdine)
(lies down, covered by his gaberdine)
paragraphs.translated:
Hey, look over there! Here comes one of his spirits to torture me for taking so long to bring the wood back. I'll lie down and hide. Maybe he won't see me. (he lies down and covers himself with his cloak)
(he lies down and covers himself with his cloak)

paragraphs.original:
Here's neither bush nor shrub to bear off any weather at all.
And another storm brewing, I hear it sing i' th' wind. Yond same black cloud, yond huge one, looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor. If it should thunder as it did before, I know not where to hide my head. Yond same cloud cannot choose but fall by pailfuls. (sees CALIBAN)
(sees
)

What have we here? A man or a fish? Dead or alive? A fish. He smells like a fish, a very ancient and fish-like smell, a kind of not-of-the-newest poor-john. A strange fish! Were I in England now, as once I was, and had but this fish painted, not a holiday fool there but would give a piece of silver. There would this monster make a man. Any strange beast there makes a man. When they will not give a doit to relieve a lame beggar, they will lay out ten to see a dead Indian. Legged like a man and his fins like arms! Warm, o' my troth. I do now let loose my opinion, hold it no longer: this is no fish, but an islander that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt.
paragraphs.translated: What do we have here, a man or a fish? Whew, he stinks like a fish - an old salted fish, not a fresh-caught one. A strange fish. If I were in England now, like I was once, and I had even a painted picture of this fish, every fool there would give me a piece of silver to look at it. In England this strange monster would be just like a man. Any strange beast there can be considered a man. The men there won't give a penny to a lame beggar, but they'll pay ten cents to look at a freak show exhibit. This guy has legs like a man but fins for arms! And he's still warm, by God. I guess this is not a fish, but a native who got struck by lightning just now.

paragraphs.original: Thunder
paragraphs.translated: Thunder.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, the storm is come again! My best way is to creep under his gaberdine. There is no other shelter hereabouts. Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows. I will here shroud till the dregs of the storm be past.
(crawls under gaberdine)
(crawls under gaberdine)
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, here comes the storm again. The best thing to do is crawl under his cloak. There's no other shelter around here. In emergencies you meet the strangest folks. I'll just stay here till the storm passes. (he crawls under CALIBAN 's cloak)
(he crawls under
's cloak)

paragraphs.original: Enter STEPHANO, singing
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO enters, singing.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
I shall no more to sea, to sea,
I shall no more to sea, to sea
Here shall I die ashore - 
Here shall I die ashore
This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man's funeral.
Well, here's my comfort. (drinks, sings)
(drinks, sings)
The master, the swabber, the boatswain, and I,
The master, the swabber, the boatswain, and I
The gunner and his mate
The gunner and his mate
Loved Mall, Meg, and Marian, and Margery,
Loved Mall, Meg, and Marian, and Margery
But none of us cared for Kate.
But none of us cared for Kate
For she had a tongue with a tang,
For she had a tongue with a tang
paragraphs.translated:
(sings)
(sings)
I'll never go to sea again,
I'll never go to sea again,
I'll die here on shore - 
I'll die here on shore - 
This is a rotten song to sing at a man's funeral. At least I've got some booze to comfort me. (he drinks and sings)
(he drinks and sings)
The master, the deck-washer, the boatswain, and I,
The master, the deck-washer, the boatswain, and I,
The gunman and his friend,
The gunman and his friend,
We loved Moll, Meg, Marian, and Margery
We loved Moll, Meg, Marian, and Margery
But none of us cared for Kate.
But none of us cared for Kate.
Kate had a gutter mouth,
Kate had a gutter mouth,

paragraphs.original:
Would cry to a sailor, "Go hang!"
Would cry to a sailor, "Go hang!"
She loved not the savor of tar nor of pitch,
She loved not the savor of tar nor of pitch
Yet a tailor might scratch her where'er she did itch.
Yet a tailor might scratch her where'er she did itch
Then to sea, boys, and let her go hang!
Then to sea, boys, and let her go hang!
This is a scurvy tune too. But here's my comfort.
This is a scurvy tune too. But here's my comfort
paragraphs.translated:
And would shout to sailors, "Go to hell!"
And would shout to sailors, "Go to hell!"
She didn't like ship smells like tar,
She didn't like ship smells like tar,
But liked it okay when a tailor took her to bed.
But liked it okay when a tailor took her to bed
So go to sea, boys, and let her go to hell!
So go to sea, boys, and let her go to hell!
That's a rotten song too. But here's something to comfort me.
That's a rotten song too. But here's something to comfort me.

paragraphs.original: (drinks)
paragraphs.translated: (he drinks)

paragraphs.original: Do not torment me. Oh!
paragraphs.translated: Don't hurt me. Oh!

paragraphs.original: What's the matter? Have we devils here? Do you put tricks upon 's with savages and men of Ind, ha? I have not 'scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs. Or it hath been said, "As proper a man as ever went on four legs cannot make him give ground," and it shall be said so again while Stephano breathes at' nostrils.
paragraphs.translated: What's going on? Do we have devils on the island? Are you playing tricks on me by showing me savages and uncivilized men from the Indies, ha? I didn't survive a shipwreck so I could be scared of your four legs now. I'll never run away from any ordinary man who walks on four legs like the rest of us.

paragraphs.original: The spirit torments me. Oh!
paragraphs.translated: The spirit is torturing me. Oh!

paragraphs.original: This is some monster of the isle with four legs who hath got, as I take it, an ague. Where the devil should he learn our language? I will give him some relief if it be but for that. If I can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him, he's a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat's leather.
paragraphs.translated: This is some monster of the island, with four legs, who seems to me to have some kind of ache. How the hell does he know our language? I'll help out, if only because he speaks the same language as me. If I can cure him from his fever and tame him, and get him back to Naples, he'd make a great present for any emperor.

paragraphs.original: Do not torment me, prithee. I'll bring my wood home faster.
paragraphs.translated: Don't hurt me, please. I promise I'll carry the wood faster.

paragraphs.original: He's in his fit now and does not talk after the wisest. He shall taste of my bottle. If he have never drunk wine afore, it will go near to remove his fit. If I can recover him and keep him tame, I will not take too much for him. He shall pay for him that hath him, and that soundly.
paragraphs.translated: He's having a fit and talking nonsense. I'll give him some liquor. If he's never drunk it before, it'll help soothe his fever. If I can tame him, I'll charge as much as I can get for him. He'll bring a lot of money to the person who owns him, that's for sure.

paragraphs.original: Thou dost me yet but little hurt. Thou wilt anon, I know it by thy trembling. Now Prosper works upon thee.
paragraphs.translated: You haven't hurt me much yet, but you will soon, I can tell by your trembling. Prospero sent you here.

paragraphs.original:
(trying to give CALIBAN drink)
(trying to give
drink)
Come on your ways. Open your mouth. Here is that which will give language to you, cat. Open your mouth. This will shake your shaking, I can tell you, and that soundly. You cannot tell who's your friend. Open your chaps again.
paragraphs.translated:
(trying to make CALIBAN drink) Come on, open your mouth. This'll help you talk. Open up. This'll stop you from trembling - I can tell you that for sure. (CALIBAN drinks) You don't even know who your friends are. Open up that mouth again.
(trying to make
drink)
(
drinks)

paragraphs.original: I should know that voice. It should be - But he is drowned, and these are devils. Oh, defend me!
paragraphs.translated: I almost recognize that voice. It's - But he's drowned, and these guys are devils. Oh, God help me!

paragraphs.original:
Four legs and two voices - a most delicate monster. His forward voice now is to speak well of his friend. His backward voice is to utter foul speeches and to detract. If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, I will help his ague. Come.
CALIBAN drinks
drinks
Amen! I will pour some in thy other mouth.
paragraphs.translated:
Four legs and two voices - a very special monster. One voice speaks well and talks about his friend. The other voice is harsh and abusive. I can charge even more for this. If it takes all the wine in my bottle, I'll cure him. Come on. CALIBAN drinks That's good! Now I'll pour some in your other mouth.
drinks

paragraphs.original: Stephano!
paragraphs.translated: Stephano!

paragraphs.original: Doth thy other mouth call me? Mercy, mercy! This is a devil, and no monster. I will leave him. I have no long spoon.
paragraphs.translated: Is your other mouth calling my name? Mercy, mercy! This isn't a monster, it's a devil. I'll leave him alone. I have no interest in getting mixed up with the devil.

paragraphs.original: Stephano! If thou beest Stephano, touch me and speak to me. For I am Trinculo - be not afeard - thy good friend Trinculo.
paragraphs.translated: Stephano! If you're Stephano, touch me and speak to me. I'm Trinculo - don't be scared - your good friend Trinculo.

paragraphs.original:
If thou beest Trinculo, come forth. I'll pull thee by the lesser legs. If any be Trinculo's legs, these are they. (pulls TRINCULO out from under the gaberdine)
(pulls
out from under the gaberdine)
paragraphs.translated:
If you're Trinculo, then come out. I'll pull on these smaller legs. If any legs here are Trinculo's, these are. (he pulls TRINCULO out from under the cloak) Well,
(he pulls
out from under the cloak)

paragraphs.original: Thou art very Trinculo indeed! How camest thou to be the siege of this mooncalf? Can he vent Trinculos?
paragraphs.translated:
what do you know, you are Trinculo! How did you end up as this monster's dung? Does he crap Trinculos?
are

paragraphs.original:
I took him to be killed with a thunderstroke. But art thou not drowned, Stephano? I hope now thou art not drowned. Is the storm overblown? I hid me under the dead mooncalf's gaberdine for fear of the storm. And art thou living, Stephano? O Stephano, two Neapolitans 'scaped! (dances STEPHANO about)
(dances
about)
paragraphs.translated:
I thought he was dead, struck by lightning. But aren't you drowned, Stephano? I hope you're not drowned. Has the storm passed? I hid under this monster's cloak to get out of the storm. Are you really alive, Stephano? Oh, Stephano, two men from Naples survived! (TRINCULO dances STEPHANO around.)
(
dances
around.)

paragraphs.original: Prithee, do not turn me about. My stomach is not constant.
paragraphs.translated: Please stop turning me around. My stomach's a little upset.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) These be fine things, an if they be not sprites. That's a brave god and bears celestial liquor. I will kneel to him.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) These are beautiful creatures, if they're not spirits. He's a good god, who brings liquor from the heavens. I will worship him.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Swum ashore, man, like a duck. I can swim like a duck, I'll be sworn.
paragraphs.translated: I swam ashore like a duck. I can swim like a duck, I swear.

paragraphs.original: Here, kiss the book. Though thou canst swim like a duck, thou art made like a goose.
paragraphs.translated:
Here,
kiss the Bible and swear. You may swim like a duck, but you look more like a goose.
kiss the Bible

paragraphs.original: TRINCULO drinks
paragraphs.translated: TRINCULO drinks.

paragraphs.original: O Stephano, hast any more of this?
paragraphs.translated: Oh Stephano, do you have any more of that wine?

paragraphs.original: The whole butt, man. My cellar is in a rock by th' seaside where my wine is hid. - How now, mooncalf? How does thine ague?
paragraphs.translated: I've got the whole barrel, man. I live in a cave by the seaside, where I keep the barrel hidden. - Hey, monster, how's your fever?

paragraphs.original: Hast thou not dropped from heaven?
paragraphs.translated: You come from heaven, don't you?

paragraphs.original: Out o' th' moon, I do assure thee. I was the man i' the moon when time was.
paragraphs.translated: No, from the moon, I'm telling you. I used to be the man in the moon a long time ago.

paragraphs.original: I have seen thee in her and I do adore thee. My mistress showed me thee and thy dog and thy bush.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I've seen you in the moon, and I worship you. My mistress showed me you in the moon and your dog and your bush.

paragraphs.original: Come, swear to that, kiss the book. I will furnish it anon with new contents, swear.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, swear to it. Kiss the Bible and swear it. I'm going to fill the bottle up again soon.

paragraphs.original: CALIBAN drinks
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN drinks.

paragraphs.original: By this good light, this is a very shallow monster. I afeard of him! A very weak monster. The man i' th' moon! A most poor credulous monster. - Well drawn, monster, in good sooth!
paragraphs.translated: When you get a good look at him, you see he's not much of a monster. I can't believe I was scared of him! A pretty pathetic monster. The man in the moon! What a poor, gullible monster. - That was a nice big gulp, monster!

paragraphs.original:
(to STEPHANO) I'll show thee every fertile inch o' th' island.
(to
)
And I will kiss thy foot. I prithee, be my god.

By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster.
When 's god's asleep, he'll rob his bottle.
paragraphs.translated: What a lying, drunken monster. When his god falls asleep, the monster will snatch his wine bottle.

paragraphs.original: Come on then. Down, and swear.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, then. Get down and swear it.

paragraphs.original:
I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster.
A most scurvy monster. I could find in my heart to beat him -
paragraphs.translated: I'm going to laugh myself to death over this silly monster. A rotten, foolish monster. I could find it in my heart to beat him -
Come on, kiss my feet.

paragraphs.original: But that the poor monster's in drink. An abominable monster!
paragraphs.translated: Except the poor monster's drunk. An awful monster!

paragraphs.original:
I'll show thee the best springs. I'll pluck thee berries.
I'll fish for thee and get thee wood enough.
A plague upon the tyrant that I serve!
I'll bear him no more sticks, but follow thee,
Thou wondrous man.
paragraphs.translated: I'll show you where to get fresh water. I'll pick berries for you. I'll fish for you and get you plenty of firewood. The tyrant I'm serving now can go to hell! I won't get any more wood for him. I'm serving you now, you wonderful man.

paragraphs.original: A most ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard.
paragraphs.translated: What a silly monster, to think a poor drunk is wonderful.

paragraphs.original:
(to STEPHANO) I prithee, let me bring thee where crabs grow.
(to
)
And I with my long nails will dig thee pignuts,
Show thee a jay's nest, and instruct thee how
To snare the nimble marmoset. I'll bring thee
To clustering filberts, and sometimes I'll get thee
Young scamels from the rock. Wilt thou go with me?

I prithee now, lead the way without any more talking. -  Trinculo, the king and all our company else being drowned, we will inherit here. - Here, bear my bottle. - Fellow Trinculo, we'll fill him by and by again.
paragraphs.translated: Show us the way without further delay. - Trinculo, since the king and all our comrades are drowned, we're the heirs of this place. - Here, carry my wine bottle. - Trinculo, my buddy, we'll get that bottle refilled soon enough.

paragraphs.original:
(sings drunkenly)
(sings drunkenly)
Farewell, master! Farewell, farewell.
Farewell, master! Farewell, farewell
paragraphs.translated:
(sings drunkenly)
(sings drunkenly)
Goodbye, master! Goodbye, goodbye.
Goodbye, master! Goodbye, goodbye

paragraphs.original: A howling monster, a drunken monster.
paragraphs.translated: A loud-mouthed, drunken monster.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
No more dams I'll make for fish,
No more dams I'll make for fish
Nor fetch in firing
Nor fetch in firing
At requiring,
At requiring
Nor scrape trencher, nor wash dish.
Nor scrape trencher, nor wash dish
'Ban, 'Ban, Ca-caliban
'Ban, 'Ban, Ca-caliban
Has a new master. Get a new man.
Has a new master. Get a new man
Freedom, high-day, high-day, freedom, freedom, high-day, freedom!
Freedom, high-day, high-day, freedom, freedom, high-day, freedom!
paragraphs.translated:
(sings)
(sings)
I won't build you any more dams to catch fish,
I won't build you any more dams to catch fish
Or fetch you firewood when you order me to,
Or fetch you firewood when you order me to
Or clean the plates, or wash dishes.
Or clean the plates, or wash dishes
'Ban, 'ban, Ca-caliban
'Ban, 'ban, Ca-caliban
Has a new master. So get a new servant.
Has a new master. So get a new servant
Freedom, what a wonderful day, wonderful day, freedom, freedom, wonderful day, freedom!
Freedom, what a wonderful day, wonderful day, freedom, freedom, wonderful day, freedom!

paragraphs.original: O brave monster! Lead the way.
paragraphs.translated: Good monster! Show us the way.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter FERDINAND bearing a log
paragraphs.translated: FERDINAND enters, carrying a log.

paragraphs.original:
There be some sports are painful, and their labor
Delight in them sets off. Some kinds of baseness
Are nobly undergone. And most poor matters
Point to rich ends. This my mean task
Would be as heavy to me as odious, but
The mistress which I serve quickens what's dead
And makes my labors pleasures. Oh, she is
Ten times more gentle than her father's crabbed,
And he's composed of harshness. I must remove
Some thousands of these logs and pile them up,
Upon a sore injunction. My sweet mistress
Weeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness
Had never like executor. I forget,
But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors,
Most busiest when I do it.
paragraphs.translated: Some games are painful, but their discomfort makes them more fun. Some kinds of lowly activities are done for noble reasons. And you can do poor things that lead to rich results. This hard work would be boring and nasty to me, but I'm working for a mistress who makes me enjoy my labor. Oh, she's ten times nicer than her father is mean, and he's the height of crabbiness. I have thousands of logs to take away and pile up, on strict orders from him. My sweet darling cries when she sees me work and tells me that such a wonderful man never performed such lowly tasks before. These sweet thoughts relieve me and refresh me, especially when I'm slaving away busily.

paragraphs.original: Enter MIRANDA, and PROSPERO unseen
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA enters, followed by PROSPERO at a distance, unobserved.

paragraphs.original:
Alas now, pray you,
Work not so hard. I would the lightning had
Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile!
Pray, set it down and rest you. When this burns,
'Twill weep for having wearied you. My father
Is hard at study. Pray now, rest yourself.
He's safe for these three hours.
paragraphs.translated: Now, please, I beg you, don't work so hard. I wish the lightning had burned up all those logs that you've been ordered to stack! Please put that log down and rest a while. When this wood burns, it'll weep for making you tired. My father's studying hard, so he won't see you. So please rest. We're safe from my father for at least three hours.

paragraphs.original:
O most dear mistress,
The sun will set before I shall discharge
What I must strive to do.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my dear mistress, I won't be able to finish this work until sunset at the earliest.

paragraphs.original:
If you'll sit down,
I'll bear your logs the while. Pray, give me that.
I'll carry it to the pile.
paragraphs.translated: If you sit down, I'll carry your logs a while. Please give me that. I'll take it over to the pile.

paragraphs.original:
No, precious creature.
I had rather crack my sinews, break my back,
Than you should such dishonor undergo
While I sit lazy by.
paragraphs.translated: No, my darling, I'd rather strain all my muscles and break my back than let you do work like this while I lounge around nearby.

paragraphs.original:
It would become me
As well as it does you, and I should do it
With much more ease, for my good will is to it
And yours it is against.
paragraphs.translated: I'd be as right for the job as you are, and I'd do it more easily, since I'd have good will on my side.

paragraphs.original:
(aside)    Poor worm, thou art infected!
(aside)
This visitation shows it.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) You poor weak thing, you're in love! I can see it clearly now.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: You look wearily.
paragraphs.translated: You look tired.

paragraphs.original:
No, noble mistress. 'Tis fresh morning with me
When you are by at night. I do beseech you - 
Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers - 
What is your name?
paragraphs.translated: No, noble mistress, I'm as fresh as morning when you're near me, even at night. I beg you to tell me your name so I can use it in my prayers.

paragraphs.original:
Miranda. - O my father,
I have broke your hest to say so!
paragraphs.translated: Miranda. - Oh father, I've disobeyed you by telling him that!

paragraphs.original:
Admired Miranda!
Indeed the top of admiration, worth
What's dearest to th' world! Full many a lady
I have eyed with best regard and many a time
paragraphs.translated: Miranda - the very name means "admired!" You are indeed admired, more than anything else in the world! I've looked at many ladies with pleasure, and been

paragraphs.original:
Th' harmony of their tongues hath into bondage
Brought my too diligent ear. For several virtues
Have I liked several women. Never any
With so full soul but some defect in her
Did quarrel with the noblest grace she owed
And put it to the foil. But you, O you,
So perfect and so peerless, are created
Of every creature's best.
paragraphs.translated: seduced by the sweet nothings they said to me. I've liked several women for their good qualities, but there was something wrong with each one that blotted her excellent qualities and cancelled them out. But with you it's different. You're perfect, without a rival in the world, made up of the best qualities of every creature.

paragraphs.original:
I do not know
One of my sex, no woman's face remember - 
Save, from my glass, mine own. Nor have I seen
More that I may call men than you, good friend,
And my dear father. How features are abroad
I am skill-less of, but, by my modesty,
The jewel in my dower, I would not wish
Any companion in the world but you,
Nor can imagination form a shape
Besides yourself to like of. But I prattle
Something too wildly, and my father's precepts
I therein do forget.
paragraphs.translated: I've never known any woman or seen a woman's face - except my own in the mirror. And I've never met any men besides you and my father. I have no idea what people look like in other places, but I swear by my modesty, which I value above everything else, that I'd never want any companion in the world but you. I can't even imagine one. But listen to me chattering like crazy, and father always told me not to.

paragraphs.original:
I am in my condition
A prince, Miranda - I do think, a king;
I would, not so! - and would no more endure
This wooden slavery than to suffer
The flesh-fly blow my mouth. Hear my soul speak.
The very instant that I saw you did
My heart fly to your service, there resides
To make me slave to it, and for your sake
Am I this patient log-man.
paragraphs.translated: I'm a prince by birth, Miranda - maybe even a king now; though I wish I weren't - and normally I wouldn't put up with carrying these logs any more than I'd let flies breed in my mouth. But I'll tell you something from my soul. The second I saw you, my heart rushed to serve you and be your slave, so here I am now, a patient log-man.

paragraphs.original: Do you love me?
paragraphs.translated: Do you love me?

paragraphs.original:
O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound
And crown what I profess with kind event
paragraphs.translated: Oh heaven, oh earth, witness what I'm about to say, and reward me if I tell the truth! If I'm lying, then

paragraphs.original:
If I speak true! If hollowly, invert
What best is boded me to mischief! I
Beyond all limit of what else i' th' world
Do love, prize, honor you.
paragraphs.translated: destroy all my prospects in life! More than anything else in the world, I love you, value you, and honor you.

paragraphs.original:
I am a fool
To weep at what I am glad of.
paragraphs.translated: Look at me crying - what a fool I am to cry at what makes me happy.

paragraphs.original:
(aside)     Fair encounter
(aside)
Of two most rare affections! Heavens rain grace
On that which breeds between 'em!
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) What a pleasant meeting between two people truly in love! May heaven bless the feelings growing between them!
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Wherefore weep you?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you crying?

paragraphs.original:
At mine unworthiness, that dare not offer
What I desire to give, and much less take
What I shall die to want. But this is trifling,
And all the more it seeks to hide itself
The bigger bulk it shows. Hence, bashful cunning,
And prompt me, plain and holy innocence!
I am your wife if you will marry me.
If not, I'll die your maid. To be your fellow
You may deny me, but I'll be your servant
Whether you will or no.
paragraphs.translated: I'm crying at how unworthy I am to give you what I want to give you and to take what I'm dying to have. But it's a waste of time to say so. The more I try to hide what I'm feeling, the bigger it gets. Oh, stop being so bashful and tricky, Miranda, just be straightforward and innocent! I'll be your wife if you'll have me. Otherwise, I'll die a virgin, devoted to you. You can refuse to make me your spouse, but I'll be your servant whether you want me to or not.

paragraphs.original: My mistress, dearest, and I thus humble ever.
paragraphs.translated: You'll be my wife, dearest, and I'll serve you forever.

paragraphs.original: My husband, then?
paragraphs.translated: Will you be my husband, then?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, with a heart as willing
As bondage e'er of freedom. Here's my hand.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, with a heart more eager to bear a husband's responsibilities than a slave ever wanted freedom. Take my hand, darling.

paragraphs.original:
And mine, with my heart in 't. And now farewell
Till half an hour hence.
paragraphs.translated: Here's my hand, and my heart. And now goodbye. I'll see you again in half an hour.

paragraphs.original: A thousand thousand!
paragraphs.translated: A million goodbyes to you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FERDINAND and MIRANDA severally
paragraphs.translated: MIRANDA and FERDINAND exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original:
So glad of this as they I cannot be,
Who are surprised withal. But my rejoicing
At nothing can be more. I'll to my book,
For yet ere supper-time must I perform
Much business appertaining.
paragraphs.translated: I can't be as happy as they are at this moment, but nothing could make me any happier. Now it's time to get back to my studying, since I have a lot of serious business to take care of before dinner.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO enter.

paragraphs.original: Tell not me. When the butt is out, we will drink water. Not a drop before. Therefore bear up and board 'em. - Servant- monster, drink to me.
paragraphs.translated: Don't tell me that. When the barrel's empty, we'll drink water. Not one drop sooner. Therefore, drink up. - Servant-monster, drink a toast to me.

paragraphs.original: "Servant-monster"? The folly of this island. They say there's but five upon this isle. We are three of them. If th' other two be brained like us, the state totters.
paragraphs.translated: "Servant monster"? What a crazy island this is. They say there are only five people on it. We're three of them. If the other two are as loopy as we are, our country's in bad shape.

paragraphs.original: Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee. Thy eyes are almost set in thy head.
paragraphs.translated: Drink when I order you, servant-monster. Your eyes look like they've sunk into your head.

paragraphs.original: Where should they be set else? He were a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
paragraphs.translated: Where else should his eyes be, if not in his head? He'd be quite a monster if his eyes were in his tail.

paragraphs.original: My man-monster hath drowned his tongue in sack. For my part, the sea cannot drown me. I swam, ere I could recover the shore, five and thirty leagues off and on. By this light, thou shalt be my lieutenant, monster, or my standard.
paragraphs.translated:
My man - monster is so drunk he can't talk. As for me, no liquid can harm me, neither booze nor the whole sea itself. Before I could get to shore, I swam thirty-five
leagues in it and still survived. - Monster, you'll be my lieutenant, or my flag-bearer.
leagues

paragraphs.original: Your lieutenant, if you list. He's no standard.
paragraphs.translated: Lieutenant is better. He's not standing straight enough to hold a flag.

paragraphs.original: We'll not run, Monsieur Monster.
paragraphs.translated: We're not going to run in our army, Monsieur Monster.

paragraphs.original: Nor go neither. But you'll lie like dogs, and yet say nothing neither.
paragraphs.translated: Or walk either. You'll just lie there like sleeping dogs and say nothing.

paragraphs.original: Mooncalf, speak once in thy life, if thou beest a good mooncalf.
paragraphs.translated: Monster sweetie, be a good monster and just speak once.

paragraphs.original:
How does thy honor? Let me lick thy shoe.
(indicates TRINCULO) I'll not serve him. He's not valiant.
(indicates
)

(to STEPHANO)
(to
)
Lo, how he mocks me! Wilt thou let him, mylord?
"Lord," quoth he? That a monster should be such a natural!
paragraphs.translated: "Lord," he calls you? What an idiot that monster is!

paragraphs.original:
(to STEPHANO)
(to
)
Lo, lo, again! Bite him to death, I prithee.
Trinculo, keep a good tongue in your head. If you prove a mutineer, the next tree. The poor monster's my subject and he shall not suffer indignity.
paragraphs.translated: Trinculo, speak politely. If you mutiny against me, I'll hang you from the next tree. This poor monster is my subject, and I will not allow him to be insulted.

paragraphs.original: I thank my noble lord. Wilt thou be pleased to hearken once again to the suit I made to thee?
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, my noble lord. Now would you please listen once again to the request I made to you earlier?

paragraphs.original:
Marry, will I. Kneel and repeat it. I will stand, and so shall
Trinculo.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, I will. Kneel and tell me again. I'll stand, and so will Trinculo.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, invisible
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, invisible.

paragraphs.original:
(kneeling) As I told thee before, I am subject to a tyrant, a sorcerer that by his cunning hath cheated me of the island.
(kneeling)
paragraphs.translated:
(kneeling) As I told you before, I'm enslaved to a tyrant, a magician who tricked me with magic spells and took my island from me.
(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: Thou liest.
paragraphs.translated: You lie.

paragraphs.original: Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in 's tale, by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.
paragraphs.translated: Trinculo, if you interrupt him any more, I swear I'll knock some teeth out of your head.

paragraphs.original: Why, I said nothing.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't say anything.

paragraphs.original: Mum, then, and no more. Proceed.
paragraphs.translated: Okay, just stay quiet. Go on.

paragraphs.original:
I say, by sorcery he got this isle.
From me he got it. If thy greatness will
Revenge it on him - for I know thou darest,
But this thing dare not -
paragraphs.translated: I was telling you he used witchcraft to take this island. He stole it from me. If your highness is willing, take revenge on him for that - because I know you're brave enough, I don't dare to -

paragraphs.original: That's most certain.
paragraphs.translated: That's for sure.

paragraphs.original: Thou shalt be lord of it and I'll serve thee.
paragraphs.translated: You'll be lord of the island then, and I'll be your servant.

paragraphs.original:
How now shall this be compassed?
Canst thou bring me to th' party?
paragraphs.translated: And how would we go about doing that? Can you bring me to him?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, yea, my lord. I'll yield him thee asleep,
Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, yes, my lord. I'll take you to where he sleeps, and you can pound a nail into his head.

paragraphs.original: Thou liest. Thou canst not.
paragraphs.translated: You lie. You can't do that.

paragraphs.original:
What a pied ninny's this! - Thou scurvy patch! - 
I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows
And take his bottle from him. When that's gone,
He shall drink naught but brine, for I'll not show him
Where the quick freshes are.
paragraphs.translated: What an idiot this guy is! - You're a rotten piece of work! - I beg your highness, beat him up and take his wine bottle from him. When he loses that, he'll be drinking salt water, since I'll never tell him where the freshwater springs are.

paragraphs.original: Trinculo, run into no further danger. Interrupt the monster one word further, and, by this hand, I'll turn my mercy out o' doors and make a stockfish of thee.
paragraphs.translated: Trinculo, watch out. If you interrupt this monster with one more word, I'll beat you like a piece of salted fish.

paragraphs.original: Why, what did I? I did nothing. I'll go farther off.
paragraphs.translated: What did I do? I didn't do anything. I need to get away from you.

paragraphs.original: Didst thou not say he lied?
paragraphs.translated: Didn't you call him a liar?

paragraphs.original: Thou liest.
paragraphs.translated: You lie.

paragraphs.original:
(to TRINCULO) Do I so? Take thou that.
(to
)
(beats TRINCULO)
(beats
)
As you like this, give me the lie another time.
I did not give the lie. Out o' your wits and hearing too? A pox o' your bottle! This can sack and drinking do. A murrain on your monster, and the devil take your fingers!
paragraphs.translated: I didn't accuse you of lying. Are you out of your mind and deaf too? Damn your wine! This is what happens when you drink too much. Your monster can go to hell, and you can too!

paragraphs.original: Ha, ha, ha!
paragraphs.translated: Ha, ha, ha!

paragraphs.original: Now, forward with your tale. - Prithee, stand farther off.
paragraphs.translated: Now go ahead and tell me the rest of your story. - Please go stand farther away.

paragraphs.original:
Beat him enough. After a little time,
I'll beat him too.
paragraphs.translated: Beat him up. After a little while, I'll beat him too.

paragraphs.original: Stand farther. - Come, proceed.
paragraphs.translated: Stand farther away. -  Come on, continue your story.

paragraphs.original:
Why, as I told thee, 'tis a custom with him,
I' th' afternoon to sleep. There thou mayst brain him,
Having first seized his books; or with a log
Batter his skull; or paunch him with a stake;
Or cut his weasand with thy knife. Remember
First to possess his books, for without them
He's but a sot, as I am, nor hath not
One spirit to command. They all do hate him
As rootedly as I. Burn but his books.
He has brave utensils - for so he calls them - 
Which when he has a house, he'll deck withal.
And that most deeply to consider is
The beauty of his daughter. He himself
Calls her a nonpareil. I never saw a woman,
But only Sycorax my dam and she.
But she as far surpasseth Sycorax
As great'st does least.
paragraphs.translated: Just as I told you, he usually sleeps in the afternoon. At that time you can smash in his skull after seizing his books; or you can bash his skull with a log; or you can stab him in the belly; or cut his windpipe. Just remember to grab his books first, since without them he's just a poor fool like me, and can't command a single spirit. All the spirits hate him as much as I do. Be sure to burn his magic books. He has some wonderful home furnishings - that's what he calls them - that he'll use to decorate his house when he gets one. The most important thing for you to think about is how beautiful his daughter is. He says she has no equal. I never saw a woman except her and Sycorax, my mother. But Miranda is so much more beautiful, you can't even compare the two.

paragraphs.original: Is it so brave a lass?
paragraphs.translated: Is she really that wonderful?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, lord. She will become thy bed, I warrant.
And bring thee forth brave brood.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord. She'll look good in your bed, and she'll produce some fine children too.

paragraphs.original: Monster, I will kill this man. His daughter and I will be king and queen - save our graces! - and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys. - Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?
paragraphs.translated: Monster, I'll kill this man. His daughter and I will be king and queen - God protect us! - and you and Trinculo will be our governors. - Do you like that idea, Trinculo?

paragraphs.original: Excellent.
paragraphs.translated: Excellent.

paragraphs.original: Give me thy hand. I am sorry I beat thee. But while thou livest, keep a good tongue in thy head.
paragraphs.translated: Give me your hand. I'm sorry I hit you. But try to control your speech.

paragraphs.original: Within this half hour will he be asleep. Wilt thou destroy him then?
paragraphs.translated: In a half an hour he'll be asleep. Will you kill him then?

paragraphs.original: Ay, on mine honor.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I swear.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) This will I tell my master.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I'll tell my master this.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
Thou makest me merry. I am full of pleasure.
Let us be jocund. Will you troll the catch
You taught me but whilere?
paragraphs.translated: You make me so happy. I'm full of joy. Let's be light-hearted. Will you sing the tune you taught me just a little while ago?

paragraphs.original:
At thy request, monster, I will do reason, any reason. - 
Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.
(sings)
(sings)
Flout 'em and scout 'em,
Flout 'em and scout 'em
And scout 'em and flout 'em.
And scout 'em and flout 'em
Thought is free.
Thought is free
paragraphs.translated:
I'll do anything you ask, monster, anything reasonable. - Come on, Trinculo, let's sing. (he sings)
(he sings)
Dismiss 'em and ziss 'em
Dismiss 'em and ziss 'em
And diss 'em and dismiss 'em.
And diss 'em and dismiss 'em
Thought is free.
Thought is free

paragraphs.original: That's not the tune.
paragraphs.translated: That's not the tune I had in mind.

paragraphs.original: ARIEL plays the tune on a tabor and pipe
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL plays the tune on a drum and a pipe.

paragraphs.original: What is this same?
paragraphs.translated: What's this song?

paragraphs.original: This is the tune of our catch, played by the picture of Nobody.
paragraphs.translated: That's the melody, played by Nobody.

paragraphs.original: If thou beest a man, show thyself in thy likeness. If thou beest a devil, take 't as thou list.
paragraphs.translated:
(to the invisible musician) If you're a man, then let us see what you look like. If you're a devil, then go to hell.
(to the invisible musician)

paragraphs.original: O, forgive me my sins!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, forgive all my sins!

paragraphs.original: He that dies pays all debts. - I defy thee! - Mercy upon us!
paragraphs.translated: Dead men have to pay their debts. - I challenge you! - God help us.

paragraphs.original: Art thou afeard?
paragraphs.translated: Are you scared?

paragraphs.original: No, monster, not I.
paragraphs.translated: No, monster, not me.

paragraphs.original:
Be not afeard. The isle is full of noises,
Sounds, and sweet airs that give delight and hurt not.
Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments
Will hum about mine ears, and sometime voices
That, if I then had waked after long sleep,
Will make me sleep again. And then, in dreaming,
The clouds methought would open and show riches
Ready to drop upon me, that when I waked
I cried to dream again.
paragraphs.translated: Don't be scared. This island is full of noises, strange sounds and sweet melodies that make you feel good and don't hurt anyone. Sometimes I hear a thousand twanging instruments hum at my ears, and sometimes voices that send me back to sleep even if I had just woken up - and then I dreamed of clouds opening up and dropping such riches on me that when I woke up, I cried because I wanted to dream again.

paragraphs.original: This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall have my music for nothing.
paragraphs.translated: This'll be a wonderful kingdom to live in, where they play music for free.

paragraphs.original: When Prospero is destroyed.
paragraphs.translated: As soon as you kill Prospero.

paragraphs.original: That shall be by and by. I remember the story.
paragraphs.translated: That'll happen soon enough. I remember the plan.

paragraphs.original: The sound is going away. Let's follow it, and after do our work.
paragraphs.translated: The sound is going away. But let's follow it, and then do our dirty work afterward.

paragraphs.original: Lead, monster; we'll follow. I would I could see this taborer. He lays it on.
paragraphs.translated: Lead us, monster; we'll follow. I wish I could see this invisible drummer. He really plays well.

paragraphs.original: Wilt come? I'll follow, Stephano.
paragraphs.translated: I'm right behind you, Stephano. Are you coming monster?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, GONZALO, ADRIAN, FRANCISCO, and others
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, GONZALO, ADRIAN, FRANCISCO, and others enter.

paragraphs.original:
(to ALONSO) By 'r lakin, I can go no further, sir.
(to
)
My old bones ache. Here's a maze trod indeed
Through forthrights and meanders. By your patience,
I needs must rest me.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, I can't go any further, sir. My old bones are tired. We're wandering in a maze. If you don't mind, I need to rest a bit.

paragraphs.original:
Old lord, I cannot blame thee,
Who am myself attached with weariness
To th' dulling of my spirits. Sit down and rest.
Even here I will put off my hope and keep it
No longer for my flatterer. He is drowned
Whom thus we stray to find, and the sea mocks
Our frustrate search on land. Well, let him go.
paragraphs.translated: I can't blame you, old lord. I'm so tired myself that it's bringing me down. Sit down and rest. I'm losing hope. The one we're looking for is dead. We're searching on land, but he's lost in the sea. We have to give up and let him go.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to SEBASTIAN) I am right glad that he's so out of hope.
(aside to
)
Do not for one repulse forego the purpose
That you resolved t' effect.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only SEBASTIAN can hear) I'm glad he's so depressed. Don't back out of our plan just because it didn't work the first time.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
(aside to ANTONIO)  The next advantage
(aside to
)
Will we take throughly.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only ANTONIO can hear) The next chance we get, we'll do the deed.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
(aside to SEBASTIAN) Let it be tonight,
(aside to
)
For now they are oppressed with travel. They
Will not, nor cannot, use such vigilance
As when they are fresh.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only SEBASTIAN can hear) Let's do it tonight. The men are so tired from traveling that they can't be as careful as they are when they're fresh.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Solemn and strange music
paragraphs.translated: Solemn and strange music is heard.

paragraphs.original: Enter PROSPERO on the top, invisible
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO enters above, invisible.

(speaking so that only ANTONIO can hear) Yes, tonight. No more talking about this now.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: What harmony is this? My good friends, hark!
paragraphs.translated: What's that music? My friends, listen.

paragraphs.original: Marvelous sweet music!
paragraphs.translated: What marvelous music!

paragraphs.original: Enter several strange shapes, bringing in a banquet They dance about it with gentle actions of salutations, and, inviting the king and the others to eat, they depart
paragraphs.translated: Several strange shapes enter, bringing in a banquet table and dancing around it with graceful, welcoming movements. After inviting the king and the others to eat, they leave.

paragraphs.original: Give us kind keepers, heavens! What were these?
paragraphs.translated: Heaven help us! What were those things?

paragraphs.original:
A living drollery. Now I will believe
That there are unicorns, that in Arabia
There is one tree, the phoenix' throne, one phoenix
At this hour reigning there.
paragraphs.translated: A puppet show in real life. Now I'll believe that unicorns exist, and that there's a tree in Arabia where the phoenix lives.

paragraphs.original:
I'll believe both
And what does else want credit, come to me,
And I'll be sworn 'tis true. Travelers ne'er did lie,
Though fools at home condemn 'em.
paragraphs.translated: Me too. And anything else that's hard to believe, just ask me and I'll swear it's true. Travelers have never told lies, no matter what the fools at home accuse them of.

paragraphs.original:
If in Naples
I should report this now, would they believe me?
If I should say, I saw such islanders - 
For, certes, these are people of the island - 
Who, though they are of monstrous shape, yet note,
Their manners are more gentle-kind than of
Our human generation you shall find
Many - nay, almost any.
paragraphs.translated: If I told them about this back in Naples, would they believe me? I'd tell them that I saw natives like these - since they must be natives - who are graceful and well-mannered even if they're monstrous to look at, kinder than most human beings you might find -  kinder than almost any human.

paragraphs.original:
(aside)  Honest lord,
(aside)
Thou hast said well, for some of you there present
Are worse than devils.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) My good lord, you're absolutely right, since some of you are worse than devils.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
I cannot too much muse
Such shapes, such gesture, and such sound, expressing,
Although they want the use of tongue, a kind
Of excellent dumb discourse.
paragraphs.translated: I can't stop being amazed by these shapes, sounds, and gestures, which express, even without saying anything, a wonderful kind of silent language.

paragraphs.original:
(aside)   Praise in departing.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Time to go.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: They vanished strangely.
paragraphs.translated: They vanished strangely.

paragraphs.original:
No matter, since
They have left their viands behind, for we have stomachs.
Will 't please you taste of what is here?
paragraphs.translated: It's all right, since they left their food behind, and we're hungry. Would you like to taste the banquet?

paragraphs.original: Not I.
paragraphs.translated: Not me.

paragraphs.original:
Faith, sir, you need not fear. When we were boys,
Who would believe that there were mountaineers
Dewlapped like bulls, whose throats had hanging at 'em
Wallets of flesh, or that there were such men
Whose heads stood in their breasts? - which now we find
Each putter-out of five for one will bring us
Good warrant of.
paragraphs.translated: I assure you, sir, there's nothing to be afraid of. When we were boys, who'd believe that there were mountain people with rolls of skin around their necks, with their throats hanging down? Or that there were men with heads in their chests? - Nowadays travelers commonly report that these things exist.

paragraphs.original:
I will stand to and feed,
Although my last. No matter, since I feel
The best is past. Brother, my lord the duke,
Stand to and do as we.
paragraphs.translated: I'll start eating, even if this is my last supper. It's all right, since the best part of my life was over anyway. Brother, Duke, please have some food.

paragraphs.original: Thunder and lightning
paragraphs.translated: Thunder and lightning.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, like a harpy, claps his wings upon the table, and, with a quaint device, the banquet vanishes
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters in the form of a harpy ARIEL flaps his wings on the table, and the banquet vanishes from the table

paragraphs.original:
(to ALONSO, ANTONIO, and SEBASTIAN )
(to
and
)
You are three men of sin, whom Destiny,
That hath to instrument this lower world
And what is in 't, the never-surfeited sea
Hath caused to belch up you - and on this island
Where man doth not inhabit, you 'mongst men
Being most unfit to live. I have made you mad,
And even with suchlike valor men hang and drown
Their proper selves. (some of the courtiers draw their swords)
(some of the courtiers draw their swords)
You fools, I and my fellows
Are ministers of fate. The elements
Of whom your swords are tempered may as well
Wound the loud winds or with bemocked-at stabs
Kill the still-closing waters as diminish
One dowl that's in my plume. My fellow ministers
Are like invulnerable. If you could hurt,
Your swords are now too massy for your strengths
And will not be uplifted. But remember - 
For that's my business to you - that you three
From Milan did supplant good Prospero,
Exposed unto the sea, which hath requit it,
Him and his innocent child. For which foul deed
The powers - delaying, not forgetting - have
Incensed the seas and shores, yea, all the creatures,
Against your peace. - Thee of thy son, Alonso,
They have bereft, and do pronounce by me
Lingering perdition, worse than any death
Can be at once, shall step by step attend
You and your ways; whose wraths to guard you from - 
Which here, in this most desolate isle, else falls
Upon your heads - is nothing but hearts' sorrow
And a clear life ensuing.
paragraphs.translated:
(to ALONSO, ANTONIO, and SEBASTIAN) The three of you are sinners, and Destiny made the sea belch you up onto this island - where no men live, since none of you deserve to live. I've driven you crazy, and many mad people are driven to kill themselves in desperation. (some of the courtiers draw their swords) Listen, you fools, my fellow
harpies and I carry out Fate's orders. Your swords are useless against us - you'd be more successful swinging them at the empty air, or stabbing at water, than trying to cut off even one of my feathers. My two companions are just as invulnerable as I am. Even if you had the power to hurt us, you'd find your swords far too heavy to lift. But remember - and it's my job to remind you of this - that in Milan the three of you stole Prospero's throne and threw him and his innocent child into the sea, which has now taken revenge on you. To punish you for this horrible crime, the higher powers - delaying their punishment, not forgetting about it - have stirred up the seas and all the creatures of earth against you. - They've taken your only son from you, Alonso, and they've ordered me to destroy you slowly, in a way worse than sudden death could ever be. I'll stay with you every step of your way. The only way to protect yourselves from the angry higher powers - which are ready to fall upon your head on this empty island - is for you to be sincerely sorry in your hearts for what you've done, and to live innocent lives from this time forward.
(to
and
)
(some of the courtiers draw their swords)
harpies

paragraphs.original: ARIEL vanishes in thunder
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL vanishes in thunder.

paragraphs.original: Then, to soft music enter the shapes again and dance, with mocks and mows, and carrying out the table
paragraphs.translated: The shapes enter again, accompanied by soft music. Dancing with mocking gestures and grimaces, they carry out the banquet table.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Bravely the figure of this harpy hast thou
(aside)
Performed, my Ariel. A grace it had, devouring.
Of my instruction hast thou nothing bated
In what thou hadst to say. - So with good life
And observation strange, my meaner ministers
Their several kinds have done. My high charms work
And these mine enemies are all knit up
In their distractions. They now are in my power,
And in these fits I leave them while I visit
Young Ferdinand, whom they suppose is drowned,
And his and mine loved darling.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) You've played the role of harpy very well, my Ariel. You were fierce but graceful. You said everything I told you to say. - In the same lifelike way, and with the same attention to detail, my lower-ranking servants have done what they were supposed to do. My magic powers are all in full swing, and my enemies are confused and running around in circles. They're under my control, and I'm keeping them in their crazy fits while I go visit Ferdinand, whom they think has drowned, and the young woman he and I both love.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exit PROSPERO above
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO exits on a platform overhead.

paragraphs.original:
(to ALONSO) I' th' name of something holy, sir, why stand you
(to
)
In this strange stare?

Oh, it is monstrous, monstrous.
Methought the billows spoke and told me of it,
The winds did sing it to me, and the thunder,
That deep and dreadful organ pipe, pronounced
The name of Prosper. It did bass my trespass.
Therefore my son i' th' ooze is bedded, and
I'll seek him deeper than e'er plummet sounded
And with him there lie mudded.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, it's horrible, horrible. I thought the clouds were talking to me, the winds were singing to me, and the thunder, like an awful organ pipe, roared Prospero's name. It sang about my crimes. Because of my crimes my son is dead on the ocean floor. I'll go join him there, going down deeper than any anchor ever sank, and lie with him dead in the mud.

paragraphs.original: Exit ALONSO
paragraphs.translated: ALONSO exits.

paragraphs.original:
But one fiend at a time,
I'll fight their legions o'er.
paragraphs.translated: I'll fight every one of these devils if I have to, one at a time.

paragraphs.original: I'll be thy second.
paragraphs.translated: I'll back you up.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO exit.

paragraphs.original:
All three of them are desperate. Their great guilt,
Like poison given to work a great time after,
Now 'gins to bite the spirits. I do beseech you
That are of suppler joints, follow them swiftly
And hinder them from what this ecstasy
May now provoke them to.
paragraphs.translated: All three of them are crazy with despair. Their guilt is finally starting to gnaw at them, like a slow-acting poison. Those of you who are young and active, I beg you to follow them and keep them from doing the crazy things their guilt might push them to do.

paragraphs.original: Follow, I pray you.
paragraphs.translated: Follow them, please.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt omnes
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter PROSPERO, FERDINAND, and MIRANDA
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO, FERDINAND, and MIRANDA enter.

paragraphs.original:
(to FERDINAND) If I have too austerely punished you,
(to
)
Your compensation makes amends, for I
Have given you here a third of mine own life - 
Or that for which I live - who once again
I tender to thy hand. All thy vexations
Were but my trials of thy love and thou
Hast strangely stood the test. Here, afore heaven,
I ratify this my rich gift. O Ferdinand,
Do not smile at me that I boast of her,
For thou shalt find she will outstrip all praise
And make it halt behind her.

I do believe it
Against an oracle.
paragraphs.translated:
I'd believe it even if
oracles told me differently.
oracles

paragraphs.original:
Then as my gift and thine own acquisition
Worthily purchased, take my daughter. But
If thou dost break her virgin knot before
All sanctimonious ceremonies may
With full and holy rite be ministered,
No sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall
To make this contract grow, but barren hate,
Sour-eyed disdain, and discord shall bestrew
The union of your bed with weeds so loathly
That you shall hate it both. Therefore take heed,
As Hymen's lamps shall light you.
paragraphs.translated: Then take my daughter, both as my gift to you and as something you have earned. But if you have sex with her before the marriage ceremony takes place, the heavens will not bless your relationship, but will overwhelm you with hate, contempt, and discord, and will poison your marriage bed so that you both grow to loathe it. So be careful, and make sure you respect the holy institution of marriage.

paragraphs.original:
As I hope
For quiet days, fair issue, and long life,
With such love as 'tis now, the murkiest den,
The most opportune place, the strong'st suggestion,
Our worser genius can shall never melt
Mine honor into lust to take away
The edge of that day's celebration
When I shall think, or Phoebus' steeds are foundered,
Or night kept chained below.
paragraphs.translated: I want peace, good kids, and a long life. To protect the love I cherish, I won't be tempted by any opportunity to forget my honor and give in to lust. I refuse to give up the joys of my wedding day, when I'll be so eager for my first night of love that I'll wonder whether evening will ever come.

paragraphs.original:
Fairly spoke.
Sit then and talk with her. She is thine own. - 
What, Ariel! My industrious servant, Ariel!
paragraphs.translated: You've said it well. So have a seat and talk to her. She's yours. - Come, Ariel! My trusty servant, Ariel!

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters.

paragraphs.original: What would my potent master? Here I am.
paragraphs.translated: What does my powerful master wish for? I'm here.

paragraphs.original:
Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service
Did worthily perform, and I must use you
In such another trick. Go bring the rabble,
O'er whom I give thee power, here to this place.
Incite them to quick motion, for I must
Bestow upon the eyes of this young couple
Some vanity of mine art. It is my promise,
And they expect it from me.
paragraphs.translated: You and your fellow spirits did your last assignment well, and now I need your help again. Go bring them all here; I give you power over them. Make them act quickly. I have to give this young couple here a small display of my magic powers. I've promised them I would, and they're expecting it.

paragraphs.original: Presently?
paragraphs.translated: Right now?

paragraphs.original: Ay, with a twink.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, right away.

paragraphs.original:
Before you can say "Come" and "Go,"
And breathe twice and cry "So, so!"
Each one, tripping on his toe,
paragraphs.translated:
Before you can say "Come" and "Go,"
And breathe twice, and shout "So, so!"
Each one of your servants will rush here,

paragraphs.original:
Will be here with mop and mow.
Do you love me, master, no?
paragraphs.translated:
Tripping over his own toes, making funny faces.
Do you love me, master? No?

paragraphs.original:
Dearly my delicate Ariel. Do not approach
Till thou dost hear me call.
paragraphs.translated: I love you dearly, Ariel. Don't come near till you hear me call you.

paragraphs.original: Well, I conceive.
paragraphs.translated: All right, I understand.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.

paragraphs.original:
(to FERDINAND) Look thou be true. Do not give dalliance
(to
)
Too much the rein. The strongest oaths are straw
To th' fire i' th' blood. Be more abstemious,
Or else, goodnight your vow.

I warrant you, sir,
The white cold virgin snow upon my heart
Abates the ardor of my liver.
paragraphs.translated: I assure you, sir, the tender love I feel in my heart is stronger than the sexual passions stirring down below.

paragraphs.original:
Well. - 
Now come, my Ariel! Bring a corollary,
Rather than want a spirit. Appear and pertly! -
paragraphs.translated: Good. - Now come, Ariel! Better to have an extra servant on hand than be understaffed. Appear before me now quickly -

paragraphs.original: Soft music
paragraphs.translated: Soft music plays.

paragraphs.original: No tongue. All eyes! Be silent.
paragraphs.translated: No talking. Just watch! Be quiet.

paragraphs.original: Enter IRIS
paragraphs.translated: IRIS enters.

I am the rainbow-bearing messenger sent by my mistress Juno - the Queen of the Sky. I have come to announce that Juno has asked you, Ceres, goddess of the fields and the earth, to leave your rich farms of wheat, rye, barley, oats, and peas, the hills where the

paragraphs.original:
Which spongy April at thy hest betrims
To make cold nymphs chaste crowns; and thy broom groves,
Whose shadow the dismissèd bachelor loves,
Being lass-lorn; thy pole-clipped vineyard;
And thy sea-marge, sterile and rocky hard,
Where thou thyself dost air - the Queen o' th' Sky,
Whose watery arch and messenger am I,
Bids thee leave these, and with her sovereign grace,
paragraphs.translated: sheep nibble, the furrows that April covers with flowers for nymphs to make crowns with. You must leave the groves where the disappointed bachelor lurks, rejected by his love, and the well-pruned vineyards, and the rocky seashore.

paragraphs.original: JUNO descends above
paragraphs.translated: JUNO enters above the stage and slowly begins to descend.

paragraphs.original:
Here on this grass plot, in this very place,
To come and sport. Her peacocks fly amain.
Approach, rich Ceres, her to entertain.
paragraphs.translated: You must leave these places and hurry here to this grassy spot, to entertain Juno.

paragraphs.original: Enter CERES
paragraphs.translated: CERES enters.

paragraphs.original:
Hail, many-colored messenger, that ne'er
Dost disobey the wife of Jupiter;
Who with thy saffron wings upon my flowers
Diffusest honey drops, refreshing showers;
And with each end of thy blue bow dost crown
My bosky acres and my unshrubbed down,
Rich scarf to my proud earth. Why hath thy queen
Summoned me hither to this short-grassed green?
