paragraphs.translated: Greetings to you, rainbow messenger, who never disobeys Juno, wife of Jupiter; with your golden wings you sprinkle dewdrops and refreshing showers on my flowers, and arch your colored bow over my wooded fields and grassy meadows, like a beautiful scarf to decorate my earth. Why has your queen, Juno, called me here to this grassy spot?

paragraphs.original:
A contract of true love to celebrate,
And some donation freely to estate
On the blessed lovers.
paragraphs.translated: To celebrate a marriage of true love, and give a gift to the lovers.

paragraphs.original:
Tell me, heavenly bow,
If Venus or her son, as thou dost know,
Do now attend the queen? Since they did plot
The means that dusky Dis my daughter got,
Her and her blind boy's scandaled company
I have forsworn.
paragraphs.translated: Tell me, rainbow, do you know if either Venus, the goddess of love, or her son, Cupid, is accompanying Queen Juno? Ever since Venus and her blind son plotted a way for the god of the underworld to steal my daughter away for half the year, I swore I'd never speak to them again.

paragraphs.original:
Of her society
Be not afraid. I met her deity
Cutting the clouds towards Paphos, and her son
Dove-drawn with her. Here thought they to have done
Some wanton charm upon this man and maid,
Whose vows are that no bed-right shall be paid
Till Hymen's torch be lighted - but in vain.
Mars's hot minion is returned again.
Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows,
Swears he will shoot no more, but play with sparrows
And be a boy right out.
paragraphs.translated: Don't be afraid of her company. I met Venus as she was with her son on her way to her home on Paphos, in a carriage pulled by doves. They were planning to pull a mischievous trick on Ferdinand and Miranda, who have sworn not to sleep together till their wedding day. But their trick failed. Venus went home again, and her little son broke all his arrows, swearing he'll never shoot them again, but play with birds like other little boys.

paragraphs.original:
Highest queen of state,
Great Juno, comes. I know her by her gait.
paragraphs.translated: Great Queen Juno is coming. I know her by her walk.

paragraphs.original: JUNO descends to the stage
paragraphs.translated: JUNO comes down to the stage.

paragraphs.original:
How does my bounteous sister? Go with me
To bless this twain that they may prosperous be,
And honored in their issue.
paragraphs.translated: How is my generous sister? Come help me bless this couple, so they will be prosperous and have many children.

paragraphs.original: They sing
paragraphs.translated: They sing.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
Honor, riches, marriage, blessing,
Honor, riches, marriage, blessing
Long continuance, and increasing,
Long continuance, and increasing
Hourly joys be still upon you.
Hourly joys be still upon you
Juno sings her blessings on you.
Juno sings her blessings on you
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
(singing)
May honor, riches, marriage blessings,
May honor, riches, marriage blessings
Long life, and unending joys come to you.
Long life, and unending joys come to you
Juno sings her blessings onto you.
Juno sings her blessings onto you.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
Earth's increase, foison plenty,
Earth's increase, foison plenty
Barns and garners never empty,
Barns and garners never empty
Vines and clustering bunches growing,
Vines and clustering bunches growing
Plants with goodly burden bowing - 
Plants with goodly burden bowing
Spring come to you at the farthest
Spring come to you at the farthest
In the very end of harvest.
In the very end of harvest
Scarcity and want shall shun you.
Scarcity and want shall shun you
Ceres' blessing so is on you.
Ceres' blessing so is on you
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
(singing)
Growing crops and large harvests,
Growing crops and large harvests
Barns and silos full of grain,
Barns and silos full of grain
Vines heavy with clustered grapes,
Vines heavy with clustered grapes
Plants straining under their fruit - 
Plants straining under their fruit - 
May spring follow directly autumn's harvest,
May spring follow directly autumn's harvest
With none of winter's hardships to endure,
With none of winter's hardships to endure
You will have plenty and want nothing,
You will have plenty and want nothing
Ceres's blessings on you.
Ceres's blessings on you.

paragraphs.original:
This is a most majestic vision, and
Harmonious charmingly. May I be bold
To think these spirits?
paragraphs.translated: This is a majestic and harmonious vision. Are these spirits we see before us?

paragraphs.original:
Spirits, which by mine art
I have from their confines called to enact
My present fancies.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, they're spirits that I've called out of their prisons to perform my whims.

paragraphs.original:
Let me live here ever.
So rare a wondered father and a wife
Makes this place paradise.
paragraphs.translated: Let me live here forever. Such a wonderful father-in-law and wife make this place a paradise.

paragraphs.original: JUNO and CERES whisper, and send IRIS on employment
paragraphs.translated: JUNO and CERES whisper, then send IRIS on a mission.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet now, silence.
Juno and Ceres whisper seriously.
There's something else to do. Hush and be mute,
Or else our spell is marred.
paragraphs.translated: Now be quiet. Juno and Ceres are whispering about something serious. There's something else to be done. Be silent, or else my magic spell will be broken.

paragraphs.original:
You nymphs, called naiads of the windring brooks,
With your sedged crowns and ever-harmless looks,
Leave your crisp channels and on this green land
Answer your summons, Juno does command.
paragraphs.translated: You nymphs who live in the wandering brooks, with seaweed crowns and innocent looks, step out of the water and come join us here on this grassy field. Juno

paragraphs.original:
Come, temperate nymphs, and help to celebrate
A contract of true love. Be not too late.
paragraphs.translated: orders you. Come, sweet nymphs, and help us celebrate the wedding of two true lovers. Don't be late.

paragraphs.original: Enter certain nymphs
paragraphs.translated: Several NYMPHS enter.

paragraphs.original:
You sunburnt sicklemen of August weary,
Come hither from the furrow and be merry.
Make holiday. Your rye-straw hats put on,
And these fresh nymphs encounter every one
In country footing.
paragraphs.translated: Now, you tanned fieldworkers who are so tired of August's labors, get out of the dirt and come rejoice with us here. Put your straw hats on, have some fun, and dance with these young nymphs.

paragraphs.original: Enter certain reapers, properly habited They join with the nymphs in a graceful dance towards the end whereof PROSPERO starts suddenly and speaks.
paragraphs.translated: Several fieldworkers enter, dressed appropriately. They join the nymphs in a graceful dance. At the end PROSPERO suddenly acts startled and speaks.

paragraphs.original:
I had forgot that foul conspiracy
Of the beast Caliban and his confederates
Against my life. The minute of their plot
Is almost come. - Well done. Avoid, no more!
paragraphs.translated:
I almost forgot about Caliban's horrible conspiracy to kill me. The moment they planned to act is almost here. (to the spirits) - Good job. Leave now, no more!
(to the spirits)

paragraphs.original: To a strange, hollow, and confused noise, the spirits heavily vanish
paragraphs.translated: The dancers vanish sadly to a strange, hollow, and confused noise.

paragraphs.original:
(to MIRANDA) This is strange. Your father's in some passion
(to
)
That works him strongly.

Never till this day
Saw I him touched with anger so distempered.
paragraphs.translated: I've never seen him like this. He's never been as angry and upset as he is now.

paragraphs.original:
(to FERDINAND) You do look, my son, in a moved sort,
(to
)
As if you were dismayed. Be cheerful, sir.
Our revels now are ended. These our actors,
As I foretold you, were all spirits and
Are melted into air, into thin air.

And like the baseless fabric of this vision,
The cloud-capped towers, the gorgeous palaces,
The solemn temples, the great globe itself - 
Yea, all which it inherit - shall dissolve,
And like this insubstantial pageant faded,
Leave not a rack behind. We are such stuff
As dreams are made on, and our little life
Is rounded with a sleep. Sir, I am vexed.
Bear with my weakness. My old brain is troubled.
Be not disturbed with my infirmity.
If you be pleased, retire into my cell
And there repose. A turn or two I'll walk
To still my beating mind.
paragraphs.translated: and ungrounded vision you've seen, with its towers topped with clouds, its gorgeous palaces, solemn temples, the world itself - and everyone living in it - which will dissolve just as this illusory pageant has dissolved, leaving not even a wisp of cloud behind. We are all made of dreams, and our life stretches from sleep before birth to sleep after death. Sir, I'm upset. Please put up with my weakness. My old brain is troubled. Don't be disturbed by my illness. If you like, you can rest a while in my room. I'll go for a short walk to calm down my feverish mind.

paragraphs.original:
FERDINAND, MIRANDA
We wish your peace.
paragraphs.translated:
FERDINAND, MIRANDA
We hope you feel better and find some peace.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FERDINAND and MIRANDA
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Come with a thought. I thank thee, Ariel. Come.
paragraphs.translated: Come, Ariel - I summon you with a thought. Thank you, Ariel. Come.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters.

paragraphs.original: Thy thoughts I cleave to. What's thy pleasure?
paragraphs.translated: I obey all your thoughts. What do you wish?

paragraphs.original:
Spirit,
We must prepare to meet with Caliban.
paragraphs.translated: Spirit, we have to get ready to meet with Caliban.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, my commander. When I presented Ceres,
I thought to have told thee of it, but I feared
Lest I might anger thee.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my master. When I was putting on the Ceres show, I thought of reminding you about Caliban, but I was afraid of upsetting you.

paragraphs.original: Say again, where didst thou leave these varlets?
paragraphs.translated: Tell me again, where did you leave those lowlifes?

paragraphs.original:
I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking,
So full of valor that they smote the air
For breathing in their faces, beat the ground
For kissing of their feet - yet always bending
Towards their project. Then I beat my tabor,
At which, like unbacked colts, they pricked their ears,
Advanced their eyelids, lifted up their noses
As they smelt music. So I charmed their ears
That, calflike, they my lowing followed through
Toothed briers, sharp furzes, pricking gorse, and thorns,
Which entered their frail shins. At last I left them
I' th' filthy-mantled pool beyond your cell,
There dancing up to th' chins, that the foul lake
O'erstunk their feet.
paragraphs.translated: I told you, sir, they were totally drunk, so puffed up with courage that they were getting angry at the air for blowing in their faces, and beating the ground for touching their feet - yet even when drunk, they kept their plan firmly in mind. Then I beat my drum, at which point they pricked up their ears and opened their eyes, looking around for the source of my music. I enchanted them so thoroughly that they followed me through thorn bushes and prickly shrubs that tore up their shins. In the end I left them standing in the smelly pond behind your room, with the stinking water covering them up to their chins.

paragraphs.original:
This was well done, my bird.
Thy shape invisible retain thou still.
The trumpery in my house, go bring it hither
For stale to catch these thieves.
paragraphs.translated: Good job, my little one. Stay invisible. Bring the fancy clothes out of my house, to use as bait to catch these thieves.

paragraphs.original: I go, I go.
paragraphs.translated: I'm going, I'm going.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.

paragraphs.original:
A devil, a born devil on whose nature
Nurture can never stick, on whom my pains,
Humanely taken, all, all lost, quite lost.
And as with age his body uglier grows,
So his mind cankers. I will plague them all,
Even to roaring.
paragraphs.translated: He's a devil, a born devil, who can never be trained. All my attempts to help him, undertaken with the best intentions, have been wasted. As his body grows uglier with age, his mind rots away as well. I'll torment them all till they roar with pain.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, loaden with glistering apparel, etc.
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, loaded with sparkling clothes.

paragraphs.original: Come, hang them on this line.
paragraphs.translated: Here, hang them on this clothesline.

paragraphs.original: Enter CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO, all wet
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO enter all wet.

paragraphs.original: Pray you, tread softly, that the blind mole may not hear a foot fall. We now are near his cell.
paragraphs.translated: Please walk softly, so not even a mole hears us approach. We're near his room now.

paragraphs.original: Monster, your fairy, which you say is a harmless fairy, has done little better than played the jack with us.
paragraphs.translated: Hey monster, the spirit you've been talking about, the one you call harmless, has been playing tricks on us.

paragraphs.original: Monster, I do smell all horse piss, at which my nose is in great indignation.
paragraphs.translated: Monster, I smell like horse piss, which is making my nose pretty upset.

paragraphs.original: So is mine. - Do you hear, monster? If I should take a displeasure against you, look you -
paragraphs.translated: Mine too. - Are you listening, monster? If I decide to get angry at you, just watch out -

paragraphs.original: Thou wert but a lost monster.
paragraphs.translated: You'd be done for then, monster.

paragraphs.original:
Good my lord, give me thy favor still.
Be patient, for the prize I'll bring thee to
Shall hoodwink this mischance. Therefore speak softly.
All's hushed as midnight yet.
paragraphs.translated: My good lord, I still need you to like me. Be patient, because the prize I'm leading you to will make you forget how smelly you are now. So be quiet. It's as silent as a graveyard here.

paragraphs.original: Ay, but to lose our bottles in the pool -
paragraphs.translated: All right, but I can't get over how we lost our wine bottles in the pond -

paragraphs.original: There is not only disgrace and dishonor in that, monster, but an infinite loss.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, monster, it's worse than the disgrace of getting drenched and smelly. We lost more than our honor when we lost our wine.

paragraphs.original: That's more to me than my wetting. Yet this is your harmless fairy, monster.
paragraphs.translated: That upsets me much more than getting wet. And you called the fairy creature harmless, monster.

paragraphs.original: I will fetch off my bottle, though I be o'er ears for my labor.
paragraphs.translated: I'll get my bottle back if it's the last thing I do.

paragraphs.original:
Prithee, my king, be quiet. Seest thou here,
This is the mouth o' th' cell. No noise, and enter.
Do that good mischief which may make this island
Thine own for ever, and I, thy Caliban,
For aye thy foot-licker.
paragraphs.translated: Please, my king, be quiet. Look here, this is the entrance to his room. Be silent and go in. Do the deed that will make this island yours forever, and will make me, Caliban, your worshipful foot-licker.

paragraphs.original: Give me thy hand. I do begin to have bloody thoughts.
paragraphs.translated: Give me your hand. I'm starting to feel murderous urges.

paragraphs.original:
(seeing the apparel)
(seeing the apparel)
O King Stephano! O peer, O worthy Stephano, look what a wardrobe here is for thee!
paragraphs.translated:
(seeing the clothes) Oh, King Stephano! Worthy Stephano, look at the fabulous wardrobe waiting for you here!
(seeing the clothes)

paragraphs.original: Let it alone, thou fool. It is but trash.
paragraphs.translated: Leave it alone, you fool. It's worthless.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, ho, monster, we know what belongs to a frippery. - 
(puts on a gown) O King Stephano!
(puts on a gown)
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, monster, we know secondhand clothes when we see them. - (he puts on one of the gowns) Oh, King Stephano!
(he puts on one of the gowns)

paragraphs.original: Put off that gown, Trinculo. By this hand, I'll have that gown.
paragraphs.translated: Take off that gown, Trinculo. I swear that gown's for me.

paragraphs.original: Thy grace shall have it.
paragraphs.translated: You can have it then, your highness.

paragraphs.original:
The dropsy drown this fool! What do you mean
To dote thus on such luggage? Let's alone,
And do the murder first. If he awake,
From toe to crown he'll fill our skins with pinches,
Make us strange stuff.
paragraphs.translated: To hell with this idiot! Why are you going crazy over these trashy clothes? Leave them alone, and do the murder first. If he wakes up before we kill him, he'll never stop punishing us.

paragraphs.original: Be you quiet, monster. - Mistress line, is not this my jerkin? Now is the jerkin under the line. - Now, jerkin, you are like to lose your hair and prove a bald jerkin.
paragraphs.translated:
Shut up, monster. - Madame tree, is this jacket for me? Thank you kindly. The tree's lost its jacket. (he takes a jacket hanging on the tree) - Now the jacket might lose its fur trim and become a bald jacket.
(he takes a jacket hanging on the tree) -

paragraphs.original: Do, do. We steal by line and level, an 't like your grace.
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead, take it. We're stealing things the right way here.

paragraphs.original: I thank thee for that jest. Here's a garment for 't. Wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country. "Steal by line and level" is an excellent pass of pate. There's another garment for 't.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you for that joke. Here, I'll give you some clothes to show my gratitude. As king of this country I like to reward wit when I hear it. "Stealing things the right way" is a great line. Here's another jacket to say thanks.

paragraphs.original: Monster, come, put some lime upon your fingers, and away with the rest.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, monster, put some glue on your fingers, and carry away the rest of these clothes for us.

paragraphs.original:
I will have none on 't. We shall lose our time,
And all be turned to barnacles or to apes
With foreheads villainous low.
paragraphs.translated: I won't have any of this. We're wasting our time. We'll miss our chance and be turned into geese or apes with low foreheads.

paragraphs.original: Monster, lay to your fingers. Help to bear this away where my hogshead of wine is, or I'll turn you out of my kingdom. Go to, carry this.
paragraphs.translated: Monster, use your fingers. Help us carry these clothes to where my barrel of wine is hidden, or I'll kick you out of my kingdom. Go on, take them.

paragraphs.original: And this.
paragraphs.translated: Take these too.

paragraphs.original: Ay, and this.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and these.

paragraphs.original: A noise of hunters heard Enter divers spirits, in shape of dogs and hounds, hunting them about, PROSPERO and ARIEL setting them on
paragraphs.translated: A noise of hunters is heard. Various spirits enter disguised as dogs and hounds, chasing STEPHANO, TRINCULO, and CALIBAN around. PROSPERO and ARIEL follow them, urging the dogs on.

paragraphs.original: Hey, Mountain, hey!
paragraphs.translated: Hey, Mountain, hey!

paragraphs.original: Silver. There it goes, Silver!
paragraphs.translated: Silver. There they go, Silver!

paragraphs.original: Fury, Fury! - There, Tyrant, there. Hark, hark!
paragraphs.translated: Fury, Fury! - Get over there, Tyrant, there. Listen, listen!

paragraphs.original: Spirits drive out CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO are chased away.

paragraphs.original:
Go charge my goblins that they grind their joints
With dry convulsions, shorten up their sinews
With agèd cramps, and more pinch-spotted make them
Than pard or cat o' mountain.
paragraphs.translated: Ariel, go order my goblin servants to make these fellows' bones ache, give them muscle cramps all over, and give them more bruises than leopards have spots.

paragraphs.original: Hark, they roar.
paragraphs.translated: Listen they're howling.

paragraphs.original:
Let them be hunted soundly. At this hour
Lie at my mercy all mine enemies.
Shortly shall all my labors end, and thou
Shalt have the air at freedom. For a little
Follow, and do me service.
paragraphs.translated: Hunt them down. Now all my enemies are at my mercy. Soon all my work will be done, and you'll be free. Just obey me a little bit longer.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter PROSPERO in his magic robes and ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO enters in his magic robes, with ARIEL.

paragraphs.original:
Now does my project gather to a head.
My charms crack not, my spirits obey, and time
Goes upright with his carriage. How's the day?
paragraphs.translated: My plans are almost at their climax. My spells are working well, my spirits are obeying me, and everything is right on schedule. What time is it?

paragraphs.original:
On the sixth hour, at which time, my lord,
You said our work should cease.
paragraphs.translated: It's after six o'clock, my lord, when you said our work would be finished.

paragraphs.original:
I did say so
When first I raised the tempest. Say, my spirit,
How fares the king and 's followers?
paragraphs.translated: That's what I said when I first conjured the tempest. Tell me, spirit, how's the king and his entourage?

paragraphs.original:
Confined together
In the same fashion as you gave in charge,
Just as you left them, all prisoners, sir,
In the line grove which weather-fends your cell.
They cannot budge till your release. The king,
His brother, and yours, abide all three distracted,
And the remainder mourning over them,
Brimful of sorrow and dismay. But chiefly
Him that you termed, sir, "the good old Lord Gonzalo,"
His tears run down his beard like winter's drops
From eaves of reeds. Your charm so strongly works 'em
That if you now beheld them, your affections
Would become tender.
paragraphs.translated: All cooped up together, just as you ordered, all imprisoned in the grove of linden trees that protects your room from bad weather. They can't move till you release them. The king, his brother, and your brother are all waiting there in a crazed state of mind, and the rest are grieving over them, sad and astonished. "Good old lord Gonzalo," as you call him, is saddest of all, with tears running down his beard. Your magic spell has such an effect on them that if you saw them now, you'd feel sorry for them.

paragraphs.original: Dost thou think so, spirit?
paragraphs.translated: Do you think so, spirit?

paragraphs.original: Mine would, sir, were I human.
paragraphs.translated: I'd feel sorry for them, if I were human.

paragraphs.original:
And mine shall.
Hast thou, which art but air, a touch, a feeling
Of their afflictions, and shall not myself,
One of their kind, that relish all as sharply
Passion as they, be kindlier moved than thou art?
Though with their high wrongs I am struck to th' quick,
Yet with my nobler reason 'gainst my fury
Do I take part. The rarer action is
In virtue than in vengeance. They being penitent,
The sole drift of my purpose doth extend
Not a frown further. Go release them, Ariel.
My charms I'll break, their senses I'll restore,
And they shall be themselves.
paragraphs.translated: I will too. You're made of air, so if even you feel sorry for them, imagine the pity that I'll feel, being one of their own human race. I suffer pain just as much as they do, so I'll sympathize far more than you. Though I'm indignant about their evil deeds, I'll go with my nobler instincts, which tell me to feel some compassion for them. It's better to act virtuously rather than vengefully. Now that they're sorry, I don't want anything more. Go release them, Ariel. I'll break my spells and bring them back to their senses, and they'll feel like themselves again.

paragraphs.original: I'll fetch them, sir.
paragraphs.translated: I'll go get them, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.

paragraphs.original:
(tracing a circle on the ground)
(tracing a circle on the ground)
Ye elves of hills, brooks, standing lakes, and groves,
And ye that on the sands with printless foot
Do chase the ebbing Neptune and do fly him
When he comes back; you demi-puppets that
By moonshine do the green sour ringlets make,
Whereof the ewe not bites; and you whose pastime
Is to make midnight mushrooms, that rejoice
To hear the solemn curfew; by whose aid,
Weak masters though ye be, I have bedimmed
The noontide sun, called forth the mutinous winds,
And 'twixt the green sea and the azured vault
Set roaring war - to th' dread rattling thunder
Have I given fire, and rifted Jove's stout oak
paragraphs.translated:
(drawing a large circle on the stage with his staff) I've darkened the noontime sun with the aid of you elves who live in the hills and brooks and groves, and you who chase the sea on the beach without leaving footprints in the sand, and run away when the waves come back; and you who make toadstools while the moon shines; who make mushrooms as a hobby after the evening bell has rung. With your help I've called up the angry winds, and set the green sea and blue sky at war with each other. I've given lightning to the thunderclouds, and burned up Jupiter's beloved oak.
(drawing a large circle on the stage with his staff)

paragraphs.original:
With his own bolt;
the strong-based promontory
Have I made shake, and by the spurs plucked up
The pine and cedar; graves at my command
Have waked their sleepers, oped, and let 'em forth
By my so potent art. But this rough magic
I here abjure, and when I have required
Some heavenly music, which even now I do,
To work mine end upon their senses that
This airy charm is for, I'll break my staff,
Bury it certain fathoms in the earth,
And deeper than did ever plummet sound
I'll drown my book.
paragraphs.translated: With his own lightning bolts; I've shaken up the sturdy cliffs and uprooted pines and cedars; I've opened up graves and awakened the corpses sleeping in them, letting them out with my powerful magic. But I surrender all this magic now, when I've summoned some heavenly music to cast a spell, as I'm doing now, I'll break my staff and bury it far underground, and throw my book of magic spells deeper into the sea than any anchor ever sank.

paragraphs.original: Solemn music
paragraphs.translated: Solemn music plays.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL before, Then ALONSO, with a frantic gesture, attended by GONZALO; SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO in like manner, attended by ADRIAN and FRANCISCO - they all enter the circle which PROSPERO had made, and there stand charmed; which PROSPERO observing, speaks:
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, followed by ALONSO gesturing frantically, accompanied by GONZALO. SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO enter in the same way, accompanied by ADRIAN and FRANCISCO. They all enter the circle that PROSPERO has drawn and stand there under a spell. PROSPERO, watching all of this, speaks, though the others do not hear him.

paragraphs.original:
A solemn air and the best comforter
To an unsettled fancy cure thy brains,
Now useless, boiled within thy skull. - There stand,
For you are spell-stopped. - 
(to GONZALO) Holy Gonzalo, honorable man,
(to
)
Mine eyes, ev'n sociable to the show of thine,
Fall fellowly drops.
(aside)    The charm dissolves apace,
(aside)
And as the morning steals upon the night,
Melting the darkness, so their rising senses
Begin to chase the ignorant fumes that mantle
Their clearer reason. - 
(to GONZALO)     O good Gonzalo,
(to
)
My true preserver and a loyal sir

To him you follow'st, I will pay thy graces
Home both in word and deed. - 
(to ALONSO)     Most cruelly
(to
)
Didst thou, Alonso, use me and my daughter.
Thy brother was a furtherer in the act. - 
(to SEBASTIAN) Thou art pinched for 't now, Sebastian. - 
(to
)
(to ANTONIO)Flesh and blood,
(to
)
You brother mine, that entertained ambition,
Expelled remorse and nature, whom, with Sebastian,
Whose inward pinches therefore are most strong,
Would here have killed your king - I do forgive thee,
Unnatural though thou art.
(aside)     Their understanding
(aside)
Begins to swell, and the approaching tide
Will shortly fill the reasonable shore
That now lies foul and muddy. Not one of them
That yet looks on me, or would know me. - 
(to ARIEL)      Ariel,
(to
)
Fetch me the hat and rapier in my cell.
I will discase me, and myself present
As I was sometime Milan. Quickly, spirit.
Thou shalt ere long be free.

(sings and helps to attire PROSPERO)
(sings and helps to attire
)
Where the bee sucks, there suck I.
Where the bee sucks, there suck I
In a cowslip's bell I lie.
In a cowslip's bell I lie
There I couch when owls do cry.
There I couch when owls do cry
On the bat's back I do fly
On the bat's back I do fly
After summer merrily.
After summer merrily
Merrily, merrily shall I live now
Merrily, merrily shall I live now
Under the blossom that hangs on the bough.
Under the blossom that hangs on the bough
paragraphs.translated:
(he sings and helps PROSPERO dress)
(he sings and helps
dress)
Where the bee drinks, I drink dew.
Where the bee drinks, I drink dew
I lie in the cup of a cowslip flower.
I lie in the cup of a cowslip flower
I sleep there when the owls hoot.
I sleep there when the owls hoot
I fly on a bat's back,
I fly on a bat's back
following the summer around the globe.
following the summer around the globe
Happily, happily I will live now
Happily, happily I will live now
Under the blossom that hangs on the bough.
Under the blossom that hangs on the bough

paragraphs.original:
Why, that's my dainty Ariel. I shall miss thee,
But yet thou shalt have freedom. - So, so, so. - 
To the king's ship, invisible as thou art.
There shalt thou find the mariners asleep
paragraphs.translated: Why, that's my dainty Ariel singing now. I'll miss you, Ariel, but you'll be free. - Yes, you will, yes. - Go to the king's ship in your invisible state. There you'll find the sailors asleep below deck. Find the Master and

paragraphs.original:
Under the hatches. The Master and the Boatswain
Being awake, enforce them to this place,
And presently, I prithee.
paragraphs.translated: Boatswain, who will be awake, and bring them here right away, please.

paragraphs.original:
I drink the air before me, and return
Or ere your pulse twice beat.
paragraphs.translated: I'll go so fast I'll burn up the air, and come back in two heartbeats.

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.

paragraphs.original:
All torment, trouble, wonder, and amazement
Inhabits here. Some heavenly power guide us
Out of this fearful country!
paragraphs.translated: This place is full of trouble, torments, and amazements. Please come, heavenly powers, and guide us out of this godforsaken country!

paragraphs.original:
(to ALONSO)     Behold, sir King,
(to
)
The wrongèd Duke of Milan, Prospero.
For more assurance that a living prince
Does now speak to thee, I embrace thy body.
And to thee and thy company I bid
A hearty welcome. (embraces ALONSO)
(embraces
)

Whe'er thou beest he or no,
Or some enchanted trifle to abuse me,
As late I have been, I not know. Thy pulse
Beats as of flesh and blood. And since I saw thee,
Th' affliction of my mind amends, with which
I fear a madness held me. This must crave - 
An if this be at all - a most strange story.
Thy dukedom I resign and do entreat
Thou pardon me my wrongs. But how should Prospero
Be living and be here?
paragraphs.translated: Whether you're really him or whether this is some magic trick like I was recently subjected to, I don't know. Your heart beats like you were real, and ever since I saw you, I feel my mind becoming sane again, released from its earlier insanity. There must be a strange explanation for this - if it's true. I surrender your dukedom and beg you to forgive me all my crimes. But how is it possible that Prospero's alive and well and living on this island?

paragraphs.original:
(to GONZALO)    First, noble friend,
(to
)
Let me embrace thine age, whose honor cannot
Be measured or confined.

Whether this be
Or be not, I'll not swear.
paragraphs.translated: I won't bet on whether or not any of this is real.

paragraphs.original:
You do yet taste
Some subtleties o' th' isle, that will not let you
Believe things certain. Welcome, my friends all.
(aside to SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO)
(aside to
and
)
But you, my brace of lords, were I so minded,
I here could pluck his highness' frown upon you
And justify you traitors. At this time
I will tell no tales.
paragraphs.translated:
You're still experiencing some of the little quirks of this island, which makes so many things seem uncertain. Welcome, my friends. (speaking so that only SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO can hear) But you two lords, if I felt like it, I could turn you in as the traitors you are. But as for now, I won't say a word.
(speaking so that only
and
can hear)

paragraphs.original: The devil speaks in him.
paragraphs.translated: It's the devil speaking through him.

paragraphs.original:
No. - (to ANTONIO)
(to
)
For you, most wicked sir, whom to call brother
Would even infect my mouth, I do forgive
Thy rankest fault, all of them, and require
My dukedom of thee, which perforce, I know,
Thou must restore.

If thou beest Prospero,
Give us particulars of thy preservation,
How thou hast met us here, whom three hours since
Were wracked upon this shore, where I have lost - 
How sharp the point of this remembrance is!
My dear son Ferdinand.
paragraphs.translated: If you're Prospero, give us the details of how you were saved, how you met us here, when we were just shipwrecked here three hours ago, when I lost - How painful the memory is! - my dear son Ferdinand

paragraphs.original: I am woe for 't, sir.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sorry about that, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Irreparable is the loss, and patience
Says it is past her cure.
paragraphs.translated: No one can undo this loss of mine, and trying to endure it patiently doesn't help.

paragraphs.original:
I rather think
You have not sought her help, of whose soft grace
For the like loss I have her sovereign aid,
And rest myself content.
paragraphs.translated: I don't think you've tried to endure it. Being patient has helped me a lot, for I have suffered a loss similar to yours.

paragraphs.original: You the like loss?
paragraphs.translated: You suffered a loss like mine?

paragraphs.original:
As great to me as late. And supportable
To make the dear loss have I means much weaker
Than you may call to comfort you, for I
Have lost my daughter.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, just as great and just as recent. And I have much less to comfort me than you do, since I've lost my daughter.

paragraphs.original:
A daughter?
O heavens, that they were living both in Naples,
The king and queen there! That they were, I wish
Myself were mudded in that oozy bed
Where my son lies. - When did you lose your daughter?
paragraphs.translated: A daughter? Oh God, I wish the two of them were alive and living in Naples, as king and queen! I'd give up my life and take my son's place in the mud on the ocean floor if I could see them alive in Naples. - When did you lose your daughter?

paragraphs.original:
In this last tempest. I perceive these lords
At this encounter do so much admire
That they devour their reason and scarce think
Their eyes do offices of truth, their words
Are natural breath. - But howsoev'r you have
Been justled from your senses, know for certain
That I am Prospero and that very duke
Which was thrust forth of Milan, who most strangely
Upon this shore where you were wracked, was landed,
To be the lord on 't.
paragraphs.translated: In this recent storm. These lords seem so astonished that they've lost their use of reason and can hardly believe what they see with their own eyes. - But whatever the reason for your losing your senses, you can know for sure that I'm Prospero, that same duke who was kicked out of Milan and landed on this same island where you landed, and became the lord of it. No more of this story now, for it takes days to tell, not just a chat over breakfast or during this first meeting of ours.

paragraphs.original:
No more yet of this,
For 'tis a chronicle of day by day,
Not a relation for a breakfast, nor
Befitting this first meeting.
(to ALONSO)  Welcome, sir.
(to
)
This cell's my court. Here have I few attendants
And subjects none abroad. Pray you, look in.
My dukedom since you have given me again,
I will requite you with as good a thing,
At least bring forth a wonder to content ye
As much as me my dukedom.
Here PROSPERO uncovers FERDINAND and MIRANDA playing at chess
paragraphs.translated: PROSPERO draws a curtain to reveal FERDINAND and MIRANDA playing chess.

paragraphs.original:
No, my dearest love,
I would not for the world.
paragraphs.translated: No, my dearest love, I wouldn't cheat you for the whole world.

paragraphs.original:
Yes, for a score of kingdoms you should wrangle,
And I would call it fair play.
paragraphs.translated: Maybe not the whole world, but you'd cheat for twenty kingdoms. But even then I'd still lie and say you were playing by the rules.

paragraphs.original:
If this prove
A vision of the Island, one dear son
Shall I twice lose.
paragraphs.translated: If this dream vision is typical of what this island conjures up, then I'll lose my son twice.

paragraphs.original: A most high miracle!
paragraphs.translated: A wonderful miracle!

paragraphs.original:
(seeing ALONSO and kneeling)
(seeing
and kneeling)
Though the seas threaten, they are merciful.
I have cursed them without cause.
paragraphs.translated:
(seeing ALONSO and kneeling) The seas may threaten us, but they show mercy sometimes too. I cursed them for no reason.
(seeing
and kneeling)

paragraphs.original:
Now all the blessings
Of a glad father, compass thee about.
Arise, and say how thou camest here.
paragraphs.translated: Receive all the blessings of a happy father. Get up and tell me how you came here.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, wonder!
How many goodly creatures are there here!
How beauteous mankind is! O brave new world,
That has such people in 't!
paragraphs.translated: How amazing! How many wonderful creatures there are here! Mankind is so beautiful! Oh, what a wonderful new world, that has such people in it!

paragraphs.original: 'Tis new to thee.
paragraphs.translated: It's new to you.

paragraphs.original:
(to FERDINAND )
(to
)
What is this maid with whom thou wast at play?
Your eld'st acquaintance cannot be three hours.
Is she the goddess that hath severed us
And brought us thus together?

Sir, she is mortal.
But by immortal providence, she's mine.
I chose her when I could not ask my father
For his advice, nor thought I had one. She
Is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan,
Of whom so often I have heard renown
But never saw before, of whom I have
Received a second life. And second father
This lady makes him to me.
paragraphs.translated: No, sir, she's human. But by the grace of God, she's mine. I chose her for my wife when I thought I had no father to ask advice of. She's the daughter of this famous Duke of Milan I heard so much about but never saw before. He's given me a second life, and marrying her makes him a second father to me.

paragraphs.original:
I am hers.
But oh, how oddly will it sound that I
Must ask my child forgiveness!
paragraphs.translated: And I'm her father as well. But oh, how odd it is to have to ask for my child's forgiveness!

paragraphs.original:
There, sir, stop.
Let us not burden our remembrances with
A heaviness that's gone.
paragraphs.translated: Stop right there, sir. Let's not get gloomy in our reminiscing, since there's no reason for sadness anymore.

paragraphs.original:
I have inly wept,
Or should have spoke ere this. Look down, you gods,
And on this couple drop a blessèd crown,
For it is you that have chalked forth the way
Which brought us hither.
paragraphs.translated: I've been crying to myself just now, or I would've said the same thing. Dear gods, bless this couple, since you're the ones who have shown us the path that led us here.

paragraphs.original: I say amen, Gonzalo.
paragraphs.translated: Amen to that, Gonzalo.

paragraphs.original:
Was Milan thrust from Milan, that his issue
Should become kings of Naples? O, rejoice
Beyond a common joy, and set it down
With gold on lasting pillars. In one voyage
Did Claribel her husband find at Tunis;
And Ferdinand, her brother, found a wife
Where he himself was lost; Prospero, his dukedom
In a poor isle; and all of us, ourselves
When no man was his own.
paragraphs.translated: Was the Duke of Milan kicked out of Milan so his children could become kings of Naples? Oh, this is cause for an extraordinary joy that should be engraved in gold on pillars to last forever. On one and the same trip Claribel found a husband in Tunis, and Ferdinand, her brother, found a wife where he was shipwrecked; Prospero found his dukedom on a poor island; and all of us found ourselves when we lost control of ourselves.

paragraphs.original:
(to FERDINAND and MIRANDA) Give me your hands.
(to
and
)
Let grief and sorrow still embrace his heart
That doth not wish you joy.
paragraphs.translated:
(to FERDINAND and MIRANDA) Give me your hands. May anyone who doesn't wish you joy feel grief and sorrow.
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original: Be it so. Amen.
paragraphs.translated: So be it. Amen.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, with the MASTER and BOATSWAIN amazedly following
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters with the MASTER and BOATSWAIN following in amazement.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, look, sir, look, sir! Here is more of us.
I prophesied if a gallows were on land,
This fellow could not drown.
(to BOATSWAIN)  Now, blasphemy,
(to
)
That swear'st grace o'erboard, not an oath on shore?
Hast thou no mouth by land? What is the news?

The best news is that we have safely found
Our king and company. The next, our ship - 
Which, but three glasses since, we gave out split - 
Is tight and yare and bravely rigged as when
We first put out to sea.
paragraphs.translated: The best news of all is that we've located our king and our men. The next bit of good news is that our ship - which we gave up for ruined only three hours ago - is as well-outfitted and seaworthy as it was when we first set sail.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to PROSPERO) Sir, all this service
(aside to
)
Have I done since I went.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only PROSPERO can hear) Sir, I've done all this work for you since I left you last.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

(speaking so that only ARIEL can hear) My clever spirit!
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
These are not natural events. They strengthen
From strange to stranger. - 
(to BOATSWAIN) Say, how came you hither?
(to
)

If I did think, sir, I were well awake,
I'd strive to tell you. We were dead of sleep
And - how, we know not - all clapped under hatches,
Where but even now with strange and several noises
Of roaring, shrieking, howling, jingling chains,
And more diversity of sounds, all horrible,
We were awaked, straightway at liberty,
Where we, in all her trim, freshly beheld
Our royal, good, and gallant ship, our Master
Capering to eye her. On a trice, so please you,
Even in a dream were we divided from them
And were brought moping hither.
paragraphs.translated: If I were sure I was wide awake, I'd try to tell you. We were fast asleep and somehow - we don't know how - we were stowed below deck, where we heard lots of roaring, shrieking, howling, and jingling chains. The sounds were so horrible that we woke up liberated, and saw our wonderful ship safe and sound. The master was dancing with joy to see it. In an instant we were separated from them, as if in a dream, and brought here in a daze.

(speaking so that only PROSPERO can hear) Did I do it right?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

(speaking so that only ARIEL can hear) You did it perfectly, my little worker. You'll get your freedom.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
This is as strange a maze as e'er men trod,
And there is in this business more than nature
Was ever conduct of. Some oracle
Must rectify our knowledge.
paragraphs.translated: This is a stranger business than men have ever set foot in before, and it's not natural either. We need some oracle to tell us what's going on.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, my liege,
Do not infest your mind with beating on
The strangeness of this business. At picked leisure
Which shall be shortly, single I'll resolve you - 
Which to you shall seem probable - of every
These happened accidents. Till when, be cheerful
And think of each thing well.
(aside to ARIEL)  Come hither, spirit.
(aside to
)
Set Caliban and his companions free.
Untie the spell.
paragraphs.translated:
Sir, my king, don't waste your time mulling over how strange this business is. When the time is right, and it'll be soon, I promise I alone will explain everything that's happened. Until then, be cheerful and keep an open mind. (speaking so that only ARIEL can hear) Come here, spirit; set Caliban and his fellow slaves free. Break the spell that enslaves them to me.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exit ARIEL
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL exits.

paragraphs.original:
How fares my gracious sir?
There are yet missing of your company
Some few odd lads that you remember not.
paragraphs.translated: How is my lord? There are a few men still missing from the ship, a few odd guys you've forgotten about.

paragraphs.original: Enter ARIEL, driving in CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO in their stolen apparel
paragraphs.translated: ARIEL enters, driving in CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO in their stolen clothes.

paragraphs.original:
Every man shift for all the rest and let no man take care for himself, for all is but fortune. Coraggio, bully-monster, coraggio!
coraggio!
paragraphs.translated: Look out for the other guy, and don't put yourself first, since everything happens randomly. Courage! Courage, you fine old monster.

paragraphs.original: If these be true spies which I wear in my head, here's a goodly sight.
paragraphs.translated: If I can believe my eyes, this is a fine sight to see.

paragraphs.original:
O Setebos, these be brave spirits indeed!
How fine my master is! I am afraid
He will chastise me.
paragraphs.translated: Oh Setebos, these are handsome spirits! How wonderful my master is! I'm afraid he'll punish me.

paragraphs.original:
Ha, ha!
What things are these, my lord Antonio?
Will money buy 'em?
paragraphs.translated: Ha, ha! What are these things we're looking at, my lord Antonio? Can you buy them with money?

paragraphs.original:
Very like. One of them
Is a plain fish, and no doubt marketable.
paragraphs.translated: Definitely. The one that looks like a fish is very marketable.

paragraphs.original:
Mark but the badges of these men, my lords,
Then say if they be true.
(indicates CALIBAN) This misshapen knave,
(indicates
)
His mother was a witch, and one so strong
That could control the moon, make flows and ebbs,
And deal in her command without her power.
These three have robbed me, and this demi-devil - 
For he's a bastard one - had plotted with them
To take my life. Two of these fellows you
Must know and own. This thing of darkness I
Acknowledge mine.
I shall be pinched to death.
paragraphs.translated: He'll kill me with tortures.

paragraphs.original: Is not this Stephano, my drunken butler?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't this Stephano, my drunken butler?

paragraphs.original: He is drunk now. Where had he wine?
paragraphs.translated: He's definitely drunk now. Where did he get wine?

paragraphs.original:
And Trinculo is reeling ripe. Where should they
Find this grand liquor that hath gilded 'em? - 
How camest thou in this pickle?
I have been in such a pickle since I saw you last that, I fear me, will never out of my bones. I shall not fear flyblowing.
paragraphs.translated: I've been so wasted since I saw you last that I'm worried I'll never be sober again. But at least I won't rot, being so full of alcohol.

paragraphs.original: Why, how now, Stephano?
paragraphs.translated: How are you doing, Stephano?

paragraphs.original: O, touch me not. I am not Stephano, but a cramp.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, don't touch me. I'm not Stephano, I'm a walking cramp.

paragraphs.original: You'd be king o' th' isle, sirrah?
paragraphs.translated: You wanted to be king of the island, sir?

paragraphs.original: I should have been a sore one then.
paragraphs.translated: I would've been a sore king then.

paragraphs.original:
(indicating CALIBAN)
(indicating
)
This is a strange thing as e'er I looked on.

He is as disproportioned in his manners
As in his shape. - (to CALIBAN) Go, sirrah, to my cell.
(to
)
Take with you your companions. As you look
To have my pardon, trim it handsomely.

Ay, that I will. And I'll be wise hereafter
And seek for grace. What a thrice-double ass
Was I, to take this drunkard for a god
And worship this dull fool!
paragraphs.translated: I will indeed. And after this I'll be good and hope you forgive me. What an idiot I was to think this drunkard was a god and to worship such a stupid fool!

paragraphs.original: Go to, away.
paragraphs.translated: Go away, now.

paragraphs.original:
(to STEPHANO and TRINCULO)
(to
and
)
Hence, and bestow your luggage where you found it.
paragraphs.translated:
(to STEPHANO and TRINCULO) Go, and put your garbage back where you found it.
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original: Or stole it, rather.
paragraphs.translated: Or stole it, rather.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO
paragraphs.translated: CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO exit.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, I invite your highness and your train
To my poor cell, where you shall take your rest
For this one night, which - part of it - I'll waste
With such discourse as, I not doubt, shall make it
Go quick away: the story of my life
And the particular accidents gone by
Since I came to this isle. And in the morn
I'll bring you to your ship and so to Naples,
Where I have hope to see the nuptial
Of these our dear-belovèd solemnized,
And thence retire me to my Milan, where
Every third thought shall be my grave.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I invite your highness and your entourage to my little room, where you can sleep tonight. But for this evening - part of it, at least - I'll tell you tales to make the time pass quickly. I'll narrate the story of my life, and give you all the details of what happened to me since I first came to this island. And in the morning I'll take you to your ship and we'll sail to Naples, where I hope to see this loving couple married. After that I'll retire to Milan, where I'll contemplate my death, which is soon to come.

paragraphs.original:
I long
To hear the story of your life, which must
Take the ear strangely.
paragraphs.translated: I'm dying to hear your life story, which must be a strange tale.

paragraphs.original:
I'll deliver all,
And promise you calm seas, auspicious gales,
And sail so expeditious that shall catch
Your royal fleet far off. - (aside to ARIEL) My Ariel, chick,
(aside to
)
That is thy charge. Then to the elements
Be free, and fare thou well! - Please you, draw near.
paragraphs.translated:
I'll tell you everything, and I promise to give you calm seas and favorable winds for your trip. You'll sail so fast that you'll catch up with the royal navy. - (speaking so that only ARIEL can hear) My Ariel, baby, that job's for you. After that you'll be free as the air. Farewell! - Please, all the rest of you, come closer.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt omnes
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Spoken by PROSPERO

Now my charms are all o'erthrown,
And what strength I have's mine own,
Which is most faint. Now, 'tis true,
I must be here confined by you,
Or sent to Naples. Let me not,
Since I have my dukedom got
And pardoned the deceiver, dwell
In this bare island by your spell,
But release me from my bands
With the help of your good hands.
Gentle breath of yours my sails
Must fill, or else my project fails,
Which was to please. Now I want
Spirits to enforce, art to enchant,
And my ending is despair,
Unless I be relieved by prayer,
Which pierces so that it assaults
Mercy itself and frees all faults.
As you from crimes would pardoned be,
Let your indulgence set me free.
paragraphs.translated:
Now my spells are all broken,
And the only power I have is my own,
Which is very weak. Now you all
Have got the power to keep me prisoner here,
Or send me off to Naples. Please don't
Keep me here on this desert island
With your magic spells. Release me
So I can return to my dukedom
With your help. The gentle wind
You blow with your applause
Will fill my ship's sails. Without applause,
My plan to please you has failed.
Now I have no spirits to enslave,
No magic to cast spells,
And I'll end up in despair
Unless I'm relieved by prayer,
Which wins over God himself
And absolves all sins.
Just as you'd like to have your sins forgiven,
Indulge me, forgive me, and set me free.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.
